did.abstract:
This is part of the large inventory for the Benjamin Franklin Papers (Mss B F85). For complete information concerning this collection, please view the
Collection Description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to serve America; in a continual state of want; applies to Franklin for aid.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Poellnitz, baron von H. H. de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New Year congratulations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Publishes a semi-weekly political and scientific periodical; sends the last number with an account of Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Instructions for procuring a further loan in France. Mission of Col. [John] Laurens.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 526; Blgelow, VII, 183).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: England's manifesto of Dec. 20th, declaring war on Holland. The English church at The Hague burnt; motives unknown. His approaching departure for The Hague with Messrs. Adams and Searle.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes for the New Year.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, October, 1906, 35.

did.physdesc: A.L.S. Fra[nci]s Lewis, in behalf of the Board. 3p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests information in regard to a late expedition commanded by John Paul Jones, in which the frigate "Alliance" took part; especially as to the ownership of the other ships, any previous agreement as to the distribution of proceeds from prizes, the amount of proceeds, the benefits received by the United states, the dispute between John Paul Jones and Captain Landais, and as to the "Alliance" since her arrival in French waters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the arrival of a vessel from Annapolis; news of the landing made by the English at Hampton and their precipitare retreat owing to a body of French troops having landed at Georgetown, South Carolina; Lord Cornwallis confined to a small circuit around Charlestown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The "St. James" to sail by the 15th inst.; will be ready to embark as soon as he receives his instructions.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1 For Autobiographical Sketch see Pub. of Am. Jewish Historical Sec., X, 101.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the business so admirably adjusted by the Hon. Thomas Barclay, Consul-General in France for America. States several instances proving the Dutch Republic's good will toward America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Exertions of Mrs. Bache in procuring supplies of clothing for the American soldiers; Rivington's efforts to turn her zeal into ridicule.
(In French.)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 527; Bigelow, VII, 188).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delighted that the wine arrived in good condition; have just shipped a cask of the old wine of St. Denis, according to orders.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His wife most eager for news of her cousin, Charles Carroll, from whom she has not heard for nine years.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seeks the position of American agent at Rochelle; movements of the Cadiz fleet.
(In French.)

did.physdesc: D.S. Charles Thomson, Sec[retar]y, and attested. 1p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolution that bills of exchange amounting to £12,000 be drawn on the American Minister at Versailles for the purchase of clothing for the Jersey line.

did.physdesc: D.S. John L. Clarkson, Sec[retar]y, pro tem. 2p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Order carrying out the preceding Resolutions of Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes a position as Lieurenant or Captain in a Boston regiment.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. It is impossible.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing an account of a volunteer review in Ireland, which his father asked him to forward.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the slightest word of encouragement, will resign his position, say farwell to his friends and present himself at Passy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have been prisoners since October, 1780; penniless and almost naked; entreat Franklin to procure them their liberty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging £150 to be applied to the relief of the American prisoners; the weekly allowance suggested by Franklin will amount to £150 per month, as there are five hundred prisoners; if this sum can be furnished regularly, well and good; but until he has orders to that effect, he will feel justified in distrubuting less.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote a few weeks ago enclosing letters from Dr. Fothergill; little thought that he would so soon have to announce his death, which took place on the 26th of December; his director, guide and friend.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transcribing his letter of September 29, 1780; attributes receiving no reply to Franklin's illness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Leaves for Philadelphia in a few days; hopes to be entrusted with a letter for Dr. Franklin's family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. La Renaudière, who, hearing that a printer is wanted in the United States capable of training apprentices, would like the position.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote some months before by Mr. Guild, who probably spoke of a bill then pending in the Assembly for incorporating a philosophical society; it is now formed under the name of the Amercian Academy of Arts and Sciences; at the last meeting several distinguished gentlemen were put in nomination, among them the Amercian Ambassador to the Court of France; forwards a specimen of Society's first fruit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering two hundred and thirty muskets at a reasonable price.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. Has no need of them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Russia strongly for Holland and against Great Britain. Letters of marque against England being generally distributed to privateers and armed vessels.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The citizens of Dublin, touched by the present situation in the West Indies, desire to send provisions and clothing; desire a passport and protection for their vessel, as well as Franklin's interest in obtaining the same from the Court of France and the Spanish Ambassador at Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry they cannot dine with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certifying that he has not disposed of any of the within mentioned certificates and that he has deposited the power of attorney sent him by Mr. Shee with Dr. Franklin.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a note forwarded to him by a book seller in Turin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Charles Hill of Bristol, who has helped many Americans in England; he is going to Bilbao on business, and being English born, he will need a passport from the Spanish Ambassador; begs Franklin's interest in obtaining this favor; such services instrumental in encouraging a humane attitude towards American prisoners in England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account for wages, etc., as cook for Dr. Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has not forgotten the pleasure he had of seeing Franklin in London at Sir John Pringle's. Desires to see him now about a matter connected with the Royal Society of London.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes for a private audience with Franklin; his former position as Commander of the Royal Frigates.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Grateful for the position offered him, but cannot leave his wife and daughter; if circumstances should alter, relies on the continuance of Franklin's favor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks Franklin's interest to procure him the position of agent on one of the King's farms.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a prospectus of interest to a lover of the arts and sciences.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing that the Dutch states have joined the armed neutrality which was signed at the Court of Prussia; force and spirit shown by the Dutch in regard to English demands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires directions for converting smoke into flame; understands that Franklin, when he invented his stove, employed a certain method to this end; has failed to find an account of it among his works.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Grateful for Franklin's kindness. Has lost everything through the failure of the firm; begs Franklin to procure employment for her husband.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards a memoir concerning certain people in the King's service; begs Franklin to procure him information on this subject.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His brig the "Whim" ready to receive her cargo; fears that the proceeds from the sale of his tobacco will be insufficient to load the brig; begs Franklin's influence with the Secretary of State to allow him to carry freight from the King's stores to M. de Ternay's fleet at Rhode Island. Any despatches may be safely confided to his care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Progress of negotiations between Russia and Holland; England's vain efforts to keep Holland out of the Alliance. Desires confirmation of certain cheering news from America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter addressed to Franklin which her daughter received from England; reason why the seal was broken; desirous of making his acquaintance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Warning as to a number of lost sets of bills of exchange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Efforts made by Sir [James] Harris, the English Ambassador at St. Petersburg, to keep Holland out of an alliance with Russia; attitude of the Empress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request from Capt. [William] Robeson for a passage to America on board one of the King's ships.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Situation of Antwerp admirable for commerce, though that as well as politics appears to have been banished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just heard that the shipment of saltpetre from St. Malo to L'Orient has terminated successfully; offers his congratulations. Has sustained a heavy below in the loss of an aunt who had been a second mother to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation to dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes Franklin has regained health. Asks him to accept as a gift the portrait of the Archbishop of Paris which will soon be engraved and delivered to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to accept his invitation to dinner as he is engaged to M. de Beaumarchais.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a sonnet (1 p.) of which Franklin is the subject; written in honor of the Immaculate Conception; it won the first prize at the University of Caen.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Holland's manifesto not yet published; fears the consequence of so much delay. Holland likely to ask of France aid for her forces in the East Indies.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's kind note and appointing a day when she will be happy to see him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the desired permission, that the books held at the customhouse may be delivered to Franklin's address without further delay.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Boston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certificate of membership.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have paid the desired amount to Capt. Nicholas Broughton of Marblehead. The ship "Marquis de la Fayette" not yet appeared.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His cousin is a printer who desires to pursue his trade in Boston; answers for his intelligence and abillity.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Chastellux, François-Jean de Beauvoir, chevalier de. Newport

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Praises Mr. Laurens in the highest terms. Franklin's letters of introduction procured him the kindest welcome in Philadelphia, from Mr. Reed and the Academical Society.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Since his last a ship loaded with sugar and cotton from Port au Prince (but belonging to Boston) arrived at l'Orient to his address. Each post informs him that the ship ["Marquis de la Fayette"] is ready but she is, notwithstanding, still at Bordeaux. If he had not made the bargain for her he could now ship the goods in American bottoms as there are two or three ships at l'Orient. Has sent M. de Chaumont his account current by this day's post. If Dr. Franklin takes this clothing he will repay Mr. de Chaumont by him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: For news of the state of affairs, refers him to Col. [John] Laurens an officer in the army and son of former President Laurens, now a prisoner in the Tower of London; Col. Laurens's mission probably connected with the great need of money. Greater degree of unanimity in the settlement of the new Constitution. Has long expected the arrival of Capt. Jones in the "Ariel"; doubts not he will clear himself of all charges against him; Landais's trial and the testimony of the officers and passengers. Franklin elected a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. The bearer of the present letter is his son-in-law, Col. Johonnot, late of the U.S. army, who goes to France to see his son; will appreciate any kindness shown them. Encloses a memoir, of which he is the author, concerning the great service rendered the American cause by Count d'Estaing; wishes it printed and published at his expense; encloses copies of his sermon delivered at the inauguration of their new Commonwealth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Saw in the Pennsylvania Gazette of Oct. 30th, some mention of the Chevalier du Buisson; his only surviving daughter is very anxious for news of her father, who went to America in 1757 and of whom nothing has been heard since.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears that party feeling will long delay the choice of a Secretary for Franklin's Embassy. Mission of Col. Laurens; approves his selection by Congress. Has sent, from time to time, authentic and accurate accounts of their successes, but dared not give a confidential account of their extreme need of money, arms,clothing, and ammunition. French force of great service in counteracting the enemy's plans. Col. Laurens can furnish all particulars of a public and private character. His own situation in America is the happiest he can ever hope to obtain. Not surprised to discover that Franklin has enemies, but the people at large revere his name. Does not know whether their little book has yet made its appearance; enemy's hellish trade will furnish him with further material, which he will forward.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The books which the bearer will deliver, were given him by his uncle, Sir Edward Newenham; has also a letter from his uncle which he will deliver in person.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing [Louis Dominique Ethis] de Corney, a member of several literary societies in Europe, who came to America with Marquis de la Fayette on public business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearer is Mr. Thomas Wynne, who escaped with his young brother from an English prison; their hope of sailing to America from one of the French seaports; has lent them a little money; leaves the rest to Franklin's known kindness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending enclosure for Congress. Talk of a general peace through the interventions of Russia; report that England has proposed a nine years' truce to France. Delighted to see Mr. Silas Deane. Account of his conversation with Mr. Searle and the French Ambassador. Conference between the Ambassador and M. G[illo]n; the latter's belief that he will soon be able to see sail from the Texel. Desiring to know if there is any Minister in Europe with sufficient power from Congress to enter into negotiations with Russia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The arms damaged on board the "Ariel" and left for repair are nearly ready for shipping; desires to know if they are to go on board the "Marquis de la Fayette."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has several talents which he thinks will prove advantageous to the Colony of Boston.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote some weeks before of experiments done according to Franklin's directions, with wires of various metals. Repeats his inquires concerning an important letter from Mr. Wharton, which he never received. Vexed at the ungenerous behaviour of the English towards his country; hopes the northern powers will no longer brook the pride and arrogance of that nation. Begs for news of America and suggests a way of forwarding newspapers. Has observed a blunder in all the translations of his "Theory of the Electrophorus," which affects the sense; will publish a new translation, with improvements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote some weeks before of experiments done according to Franklin's directions, with wires of various metals. Repeats his inquiries concerning an important letter from Mr. Wharton, which he never received. Vexed at the ungenerous behavior of the English towards his country; hopes the northern powers will no longer brook the pride and arrogance of that nation. Begs for news of America and suggests a way of forwarding newspapers. Has observed a blunder in all the translations of his "Theory of the Electrophorus," which affects the sense; will publish a new translation, with improvements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to serve in the United States on condition that he reveive the command of infantry or cavalry troops.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking that payment be stopped on certain bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him a foolish thing written for him; will be very angry if he tells anyone that she writes verse.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, Nov. 1906, 169.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The disagreeable situation of Mr. Digges; caused by Mr. Trumbull's mentioning his name in his trial. Mr. [Winslow] Warren and Mr. Brailsford both taken up; reasons why they were suspected. Mr.[John] Temple's cautious behavior saved him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing Franklin's election as a member of the Amercian Society of Arts and Sciences in January, 1781; encloses a catalogue of the present officers, the act of incorporation and the President's oration. Desires to known what publications of merit have appeared in France during the last five or six years, especially in Natural Philosophy, Mathematics and Astronomy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. [John] S[c]haffer, recommended to him by Mr. Morris of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In August , 1777, rented a carriage to a Mr. Vincent, an American, which was the last he ever saw of it; asks that the value of the vehicle be given him.
(In French.)
[A. E. by Franklin.] Advises him to write to the French Consul at New York, with a power of attorney, authorizing him to recover the property.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a bill of the Loan Office for acceptance; reasons why a bill is often refused.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Mr. Thomas White, whose funds are in Franklin's hands; desires to know for what amount he may draw.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Chaumont, Le Ray de, fille ainée. Passy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipted bill for carriage hire and wine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving particulars about the patient's [the Dowager Duchess of Deux-Ponts] condition, great improvement but still seriously ill.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a copy of a note written to him by the Dowager Duchess of Deux-Ponts and giving particulars of the latter's illness. Comments on the state of affairs in England and the reports of a truce between the belligerent powers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was taken in the " Wexford" privateer; badly off for clothes and money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if the request concerning the twenty volunteers of Capt. Conyngham's crew came to hand; they live in his house and will give him no peace until he writes again; Mr. Coffyn refuses to do anything for them, as he has received no instructions; they demand their wages and a lawful share of the prize-money.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the capture of an English privateer schooner by seven Americans, held as prisoners on board; in the subsequent trial, the privateer was adjusted the property of the captors; this judgment has been appealed to France for a second hearing; has purchased the pretentions of the seven Americans and begs Franklin's interposition on his behalf, should the appeal come before the Court of France.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Howard, William. On board a prison ship, "Security," off Chatham

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Six Americans on board the ship in a most miserable situation, without clothes or money; thay had all relied upom being exchanged with the Frenchmen; they are treated badly and are short of rations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproaches him for not coming to see her on her usual day; promises to return all his visits when she is stronger; begs him to bring her little story with him so that she may make a correction.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnma's Monthly, Nov. 1906, 169.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Being the proprietor of a large tannery, and hearing that the United Provinces are in need of a quantity of shoes, offers to supply two thousand pair a month, at six shillings a pair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. de Sartine wrote Franklin in October, 1779, in regard to the sailors of the "Revenge," Capt. Conyngham; Franklin's belief that many of them had embarked clandestinely has been disproved by their names being found on the ship's muster-roll; sends a new memoir concerning this matter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking that the enclosed letter may be forwarded to his friend, Vaillant, in Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Repeating his request for freight with which to load his brig the "Whim."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing four documents, sent to his father by Messrs. Lavabre, Doerner and Co., bankers at Paris for Franklin's official endorsement.
(In French.)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lines added by Mme. La Douairiére on the letter on February 22.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing that their invalid is on the road to recovery and that the doctors promise a speedy convalescence.
[A few lines added by Mme. La Douairière Duchesse de Deux-Ponts.] Her brother has only said what was true; she feels sure now that she will live.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Craves a passport for the Chevalier Destours, residing in Dublin, whose state of health obliges him to come to Paris.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a letter from Capt. Daniel McNeill, from St. Lucia, advising them of his capture and begging that Dr. Franklin be notified not to accept any bills endorsed to his order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The condition of Mme. La Douairière [Duchesse de Deux-Ponts] improves from day to day; she wishes to write herself but he thought best to prevent her as she is still very weak. Nothing in the way of news from Brest; vessels making ready to sail and work going ceaselessly on.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Captain [de Galatheau] of the "Marquis de la Fayette" gone to Passy; cannot guess his business; ship not yet ready to take in all the goods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the claims made by the seamen of the "Revenge"; Capt. Conyngham being dead, thinks it impossible to declare positively on the facts alleged in the sailors' memorial; was told both by Mr. Hodge and Capt. Conyngham that the latter got rid of twenty unruly sailors by putting them on a prize-ship to guard the prisoners; these afterwards got control of the ship and took her to England, where the said sailors were thrown into prison; gives particulars of Capt. Conyngham's last cruise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that the letter he sends may be forwarded by express.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires passports for American ships.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A few days before, enclosed Franklin a memoir concerning the sugars shipped by M. de Valminière from Martinique to New England; begs to be informed if the memoir arrived safely.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Quoting from a letter of Mme. La Douairière [Duchesse de DeuxPonts], which speaks of her improvement, though she still suffers greatly. Extract from her physician's letter asserting his belief in her speedy convalescence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received the little boxes from M. Grand of Paris; wishes their contents declared in order to prevent their being confiscated.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: If it can be arranged without prejudice to the United States, would like Paul Jones to take command for serveral months of a Dutch fleet, sent by the citizens and patrons of the outraged republic of Holland against Great Britain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is delighted with the invalid's improvement; thinks the battle is won and that there will no longer be any occasion to write on the subject which has so occupied their thoughts. French fleet under M. de Grasse on the point of sailing for America; greatest confidence felt in him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Royal Society of Medicine has deputed him to send Dr. Franklin tickets for their public meeting; trusts that he will not refuse them the honor of his presence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: According to the King's orders, transmitted through M. de Sartine, they were to receive a sum proportionate to the value of the vessel ["Fair Play"] lost off Guadeloupe; the estimate made by the Government of that Island falls far below the worth of the vessel; beg that justice be done them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires a safe conveyance for the enclosed letters to Dr. Price in London; begs that certain observations of eclipees, made at the Royal Observatory at Paris, may be sent to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning M. de Chaumont's consent to the appropriation of the officer's clothing to the public account.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Movements of Mr. Adams; his negotiations with M. de Neufville relative to large loan; hopes it will have better sucess than that of 1778. No apparent haste to strengthen the Dutch navy; discontent among the people.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request his opinion on the French translation of the famous Latin verse, "Eripuit coelo fulmen, sceptrumque tyrannus"; suggests various renderings; encloses one to be placed under Franklin's portrait.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in part in Works (Sparks), VIII, 538, Note.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received by the lugger "Aimable Elizabeth," a packet which he forwarded by the last post; now sends some newspapers, and by the next opportunity will forward some journals of Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most grateful for the passports which arrived that morning and desires four more for ships about to sail. His nephew and eldest son as well as his wife and himself look forward to paying their respects to Franklin very soon.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Custom house officers have refused permission to load one hundred and ninety-eight cases of musket barrels on the "Marquis de la Fayette," unless they are furnished with a passport; begs Franklin to forward one as soon as possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor with its request for certain letters and punctuation marks; will bring them in person on the first of April.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends his accounts, including advances made to sundry Americans, for which he has taken receipts; has omitted to mention cases where he only gave to prevent their being objects of public charity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets that a prior engagement denies him the honor of accepting his polite invitation to dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him when he will come and dine with her.
(In French.)

did.unittitle: to The Commissioners for Restoring Peace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extract from a letter relative to the restoring of peace between Great Britain and America.
(Press copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plan to establish a lottery in America; dilates upon its numerous advantages.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Denounces a young printer of his acquaintance, who intends writing to Franklin and asking for his picture.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing two letters from America; will send larger packets by Col. Laurens, who has just arrived in the "Alliance," Capt. Barry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just landed after a passage of twenty-six days from Boston; the expected arrival of the Marquis de Castries that evening alone prevents his hastening to deliver to Franklin the despatches of Congress, and pursue under his auspices the important matters to which they relate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Adams at Leiden. Amsterdam busy building and equipping vessels; the proposal of Amsterdam and Rotterdam to forbid all importation of English manufactures and all exporting to England of grain, linseed, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for Dr. John Foulke, whom he presumes is in Paris; offers his congratulations upon the safe arrival of the "Alliance."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring news of his brother who is reported to have died at Philadelphia with the rank of Colonel in the American army; thinks he may have served under an assumed name; begs that, if possible, a certificate of his death may be procured.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes to hear soon from Mr. Wharton, as it is nearly three months since the "Ariel" left L'Orient. Concerning the claim of the sixteen French sailors formerly belonging to Capt. Conyngham, for wages and prize-money; enclosing a petition [in French, 3 p.] which they have letely presented to the Judges of the Admiralty, in which they hold him (Coffyn) responsible for the payment of their demands; begs for a letter which may clear him of all responsibility in this matter; asks that an explanation be given to M. de Castries to whom these men have written.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Barry, John. Isle of Groix off L'Orient

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the safe arrival of the "Alliance"; the bearer, Col. Laurens, can furnish a particular account of affairs in America. Orders of Congress respecting the future movements of the "Alliance"; very anxious to obtain a copper bottom for that ship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a passport which will enable him to leave Paris, as he intends returning to Amsterdam in a few days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transcribing his own poor rendering into French of the famous Latin verse "Eripuit caelo fulmen, et sceptra tyrannis."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed that his nephew, Mr. Gurdon [S.] Mumford, has been admitted into Dr. Franklin's office, through the influence of Mr. Silas Deane; joins with his brother in acknowledging Franklin's kindness.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a stated audience to present an envoy from the Court of Spain, who is empowered to treat of affairs relating to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's kindness in admitting his son into his family until a position can be found for him in a good counting-house; has made great sacrifices in the struggle for independence, which prevents his providing for his children, as he had hoped.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In case the "Alliance" is to convoy the ship with the Continental stores, thirty or forty more men are absolutely necessary; hears there are fifty Americans on board a French privateer; as the United States may not take French sailors into service, desires permission to get American subjects out of French vessels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation for dinner on the following day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets that a prior engagement prevents his dining with Franklin the following day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring inforamition in regard to the fate of a M. Le Brun de Bellecour, who served under Gen, Washington and as Aide-de-camp to Gen. Lincoln; since the affair of Savannah, nothing has been heard of him and his father is most anxious.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Gossec to Franklin on his departure for America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects Franklin and his grandson at dinner as promised by them to Abbés Chalnt and Arnoux.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describes a plan by which a loan of 12 millions could be raised for the United States by the sale of 100,000 bonds at 120 fr. each which would participated in lottery drawings and bring more or less interest according to the result of such drawings.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The autumn before sent Franklin a little memoir concerning her brother whom she thought was serving as General in the American army; wishes to know if anything has been heard of him.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vaughan, James. On Prison ship off Rochefort

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of treatment accorded him by a certain Captain who engaged him as gunner upon certain terms; was first captured in a prize belonging to his uncle, Capt. McCulloch, and carried to England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to forward the enclosed packets by Joseph Newman, Captain of the brigantine "Gates".
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An American officer of the ship "Revenge" who has escaped from Forton Prison, in England; appeals for a loan of 20 guineas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their friends in Amsterdam, Messrs. Crommelin and Son, write that certain bills having fallen into the hands of the English, they beg that none shall be accepted without the signature of their firm.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented by Mrs. Williams's illness from going to l'Orient; loading of the "Marquis de la Fayette"; not surprised at Messrs. L[ee]'s and J[ay]'s enmity; expects nothing from Congress.

did.unittitle: to The Committee of Continental Congress

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing them of the departure of the "Marquis de la Fayette," laden with clothing for the army; denies all responsibility for the unaccountable delay.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the maps on a smaller scale; as the surroundings of Fort Pitt were given in detail, he copied them directly from the original; wishes to know if the fête of "Shawane Town," as described by Gen. Pownall, takes place every year.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin deceived by Mr. Digges; his dishonesty in regard to the American prisoners 1. Prospects of peace; intervention of the Empress of Russia and the Emperor of Germany.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This paragraph printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 15, Note).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin's company at dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote in January in regard to obtaining the position of Agent on the King's farms; as the bearer of such an illustrious name, begs that influence may be used on his behalf.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has the honor of forwarding the enclosed letter from Granville.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As Franklin has given him no instructions and as there is no one to apply to for further orders, has taken the ship the "Marquis de la Fayette" under his direction and will proceed to Delaware with her as soon as he can get ready.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to go to America and raise a company of light horse and foot; is reluctant to leave without an assurance of Franklin's protection.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wish to know if they may dine with Dr. Franklin the following Saturday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Wharton's departure for America left them without money, credit or a friend; their plans for recovering their just dues; desire Franklin's assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering to make shipments of sail cloth, table linen, etc., to America and requesting Franklin to furnish him with addresses of firms, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks Franklin to induce Mr. Laurens to come to dinner that day. Count d'Estaing has promised to be present.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing names of prisoners taken during his voyage to Boston; sorry to sail for Philadelphia without Franklin's despatches; considers it his duty to convoy the "Marquis de la Fayette" to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Everything ready for the departure of the "Marquis de la Fayette"; she is to sail under convoy of the "Alliance".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Holland's state of lethargy. England's refusal of Russia's offer of mediation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Protests his innocence; served Franklin with intelligence, attachment and fidelity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin having accepted, at his request, divers copies of bills of exchange, he hereby promises to make good the amount should originals of said bills be presented for payment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin a few newspapers; the enemy will tell their own story of the naval engagement of the 16th; they have ventured nearer the truth in Rivington's Royal Gazette than ever before; gallant conduct of the French; the enemy afraid to remain in Chesapeake Bay. Promises to send him Gen. [Nathanael] Greene's account of his affair with Cornwallis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expresses great diffidence in exposing himself to Franklin's criticism; nevertheless sends him two volumes of his works.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complaining that Franklin crossed out a signature on a draft which was presented to him for acceptance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From Franklin's silence, fears that he never received the volumes sent him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has some American paper money; desires to know the best method of realizing its value.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Vanderpar, from Iceland, who wishes an interview with Franklin on the subject of a vessel taken by Captain Jones and sent to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hears that a trunk and box belonging to him have been sent to Franklin at Passy; begs his care of them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is desirous of going to America and serving as a second lieutenant.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires Franklin to send him the French rules and regulations for a branch of their Masonic Lodge at Goerlitz. Wishes to know if M. Frosch, director of the Royal Lottery in Paris, is still a Protestant.
(In German.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received no answer to his last letter begging for information regarding Mr. Wharton's whereabouts; his reasons for being anxious on this score. Believes it necessary for the tranquility of Europe that America should remain free; attitude of England. Hopes of a Congress being called in Vienna and the American Minister being of the party. Work he has done in connection with electrophorus; notes on some new discoveries about inflammable and explosive air. Cowardly attack on Batavia by the English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received the packets and, by the first occasion, will forward them to Mr. Holker.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering to supply anything needed in the way of arms; sends list of the various kinds made in his manufactory.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Difficulty of procuring a loan in Holland; mortified at America's lack of credit.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 19; Bigelow, VII, 224).

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning certain bills of exchange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Equally shocked with Franklin at the consummate artifice and villainy of [Thomas] Digges; sends certain documents which will be proof positive of his guilt; he never applied but £30 of all the money Franklin sent him for the relief of American prisoners. Account of money received and expended by himself on behalf of prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to put in a package for Mr. Jay the enclosed letter for Madrid.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning certain duties on a cargo of sugar and cocoa brought by an American corsair to Brest; considers them unjust; applies to Franklin for redress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning cerain moneys due his mother-in-law, Madame d'Admirat, sent from Guadeloupe by her husband, as the proceeds from his sale of sugar in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After seeing the enclosed letter, amazed at Arnold's daring to show his face among men; his present employment that of stealing tobacco and negroes; Cornwallis engaed in the same pursuit. Has not yet succeeded in negotiating a loan; does not possess one grain of Franklin's faith and hope; motives which prevent the capitalists from coming forward. Desires Franklin's orders how the bills, accepted should be paid. Congratulates him on his success at Versailles. Good results to be expected, should Spain make a treaty with Mr. Jay. If America were willing to be less honest and would threaten to return to Great Britain, all the other Nations would hang themselves to prevent it; Europe's unfair and ungenerous treatment of America; would give millions to have all Europe remain neutral and let England and America fight it out alone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the enclosed letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing great pleasure at receiving Franklin's book; inserts a verse written in his honor; begs his presence at the Hotel Girardin, already celebrated by a visit from the Emperor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A promissory note for six Louis d'or.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning two boxes received from M. Grand, with instructions not to forward them without Franklin's orders.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: If Franklin has no further need of William Penn's letters, asks that he will give them to bearer; desires also a volume of the Philosophical Transactions. Wishes to know if his brother has arrived in France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers his services to America. If Franklin disapproves of his plan, does not wish his commander, the Prince de Salm [-Krybourg], to know of this offer.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reply to Franklin's letter proposing a marriage between his grandson and Mlle. Brillon; mentions the inseperable obstacle to such a union.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Pumam's Monthly, October, 1906, 36.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking that the enclosed letter may be forwarded to her husband.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advices received that the "Romulus," with a convoy of twenty transports, was bound from New York to the assistance of Arnold. Their ships' safe arrival at the Cape to a great market.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the successes of the Americans; constantly thinking of him; begs for a line from his grandson with news of his welfare.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for the information about M. de Maxwell.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notes of a correspondence between Mr. Williams and Mr. Thomas, concerning the shipment of certain merchandise to Messrs. Bache and Shee at Philadelphia.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Turgot, Etienne-François, marquis (brother of baron). Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know the method advised by Franklin for burning smoke and thus diminishing the consumption of wood; thinks this method might be employed in their kitchen stove which burns an immense quantity of wood.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petitions Franklin to indemnify him for losses incurred through an order for arms given to him by Mr. Williams of Nantes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for his kind visit, and regretting that he was unable to dine him on Sunday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His reason for requesting Congress not to make any draughts upon him until he had money to discharge them, His appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary to the States-General; has taken a house in Amsterdam. No chance of credit until their High Mightinesses determine to acknowledge the independence of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report that her brother, Col. John Laurens, passed through Nantes en route to Paris; their letters to him have remained unanswered; begs for his present address. Her uncle, Mr. James Laurens, [Jr.,] is obliged to set out shortly for England and desires Dr. Franklin to procure him a proper passport, from the French Minister, for Mr. and Mrs.Laurens and the two daughters of H[enry] Laurens, a prisoner in the Tower of London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A native of Alsace; seeks information concerning his cousin, George Mengs, supposed to reside at Philadelphia, also about his uncle, Michel Dieffenbach, an old resident of the latter city. Wishes to know whether his uncle is living or dead and what disposition he made of his fortune.
(In French. Press copy.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Des Watines de Flobecq, Louis-Eugene. Saint-Amand

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He and his family are in trouble through the machinations of a wicked young man; begs for Franklin's protection.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Warren, son of General Warren of Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tug "L'Aimable Elizabeth" cannot leave for Philadelphia for lack of sailors; despatches of la Fayette and Franklin make a speedy departure of importance; asks that influence be used with the Minister of Marine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that the enclosed letter be forwarded to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has accorded permission that the trunks containing the books be taken to their destination without the usual formalities.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Grateful for the book, which increases his knowledge of the American languages; has found immense similarity between them and those of the old world; much interested in the vocabulary of the Delawares; has discovered a Phoenician inscription near, south of Boston; thinks they may have been driven by storms on the coast of America. His interest in the American Society of Science and Arts; his plan for establishing a correspondence between the American Society and one lately started in Paris (L'Académie des Inscriptions et Belles Lettres).
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delighted with Franklin's "Dialogue with the Gout." Difficulty of procuring a safe conveyance for her letters. Her life in London. News of Sir John Pringle, Dr. Priestley and Dr. Price.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 25; Bigelow, VII, 230).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served in the American army; desires to reenter it.
E. Dr. Franklin requests Col. Laurens to inform him if he is acquainted with de Bois.
E. Col. Laurens has recollection of an officer of that name but does not know the state of his services.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Johonnot, Gabriel and S. Johonnot. Passy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accept invitation to dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request that payment of certain bills be stopped.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the loss of a small bill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His explanation of Digges's conduct; thinks it unlikely that the money can be recovered; unpleasant stories told of him during his residence in America. Thinks Mr. Trumbull a worthy character. Mr. Jones and Mr. Paradise now members of the club. Money needed for prisoners, if weekly allowance is to be kept up.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Committee of Foreign Affairs. Philadelphia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of Mr. Samuel Curson, his partner Mr. Isaac Gouverneur and Dr. John Witherspoon, Jr., taken by the English at the capture of St. Eustatius; cruelty shown to them as well as to Mrs. Gouverneur and her infant; supposed reasons for special severity; their exchange particularly desired.
(4 copies.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that his bill of exchange may be accepted.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a work by Scheele which had been loaned to Turgot, the Minister, by Franklin and which the writer claimed after Turgot's death.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Adams's memoir presented to the President of the States-General; will have it published in English, French and Dutch. Reported threats against Holland made by Great Britain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for news of his son who is serving with Rochambeau in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards M. Montieu's account; also the protest of the capture made by Capt. Jones, which he begs may be forwarded to Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving an analysis of the character of Franklin's grandson, his progress in his studies and his physical development.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposition to furnish woolen cloth for uniforms and all kinds of clothing for account of the Congress or individuals in the United States and to sell cargoes coming from that country.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a packet which he begs him to forward with his despatches by Mr. [John] Laurens; sorry to trouble Franklin, but Mr. Laurens, from political or other motives, has avoided him.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Collections of New York Historical Society, 1889. Deane Papers, IV, 334.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Dr. Putnam, also some former proceedings of Congress in regard to the sloop which Count D'Arbaud restored to the Governor of Antigua after it had been taken by Dr. Putnam and others.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to serve in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Jay declined to receive his oath of allegiance until Franklin's opinion in regard to the propriety of such a step could be learned; begs that an answer be sent to him at Toledo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bill in question has been found.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a passport for his son whom he has determined to send to an Academy near Brussels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The news from America not at all bad; has communicated it to all the newspapers. Concerning certain bills ordered by Congress to be drawn upon him, Begs that the enclosed letter, received from Gottenberg, be forwarded to Mr. Jay, with great care as to secrecy and despatch; hopes it will remove all diffculties with Spain, whose accession to the treaty would be of great value to the cause in every part of Europe. Importance to America of obtaining an acknowledgement of their independence from as many Soverigns as possible before conference for peace shall be opened. Suggests acting upon the 10th Article of the Treaty or Alliance. Encloses a memorial of their High Mightinesses. His mission now a subject of deliberation. Discusses Holland's utimate action. All ideas of peace with England false and delusive. Agrees with Franklin respecting duties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommends an armorer who wishes to emigrate to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No answers received to his letters of December 2d, February 7th, and April 7th; thinks Franklin's letter was suspected by the authorities and detained in Paris; letters from Dr. Le Bègue de Presle tampered with; directions as to their correspondence in future. His paper upon the theory of the electrophore much enlarged and preceded by an introduction of Franklin's theory of electricity, published in German. Copies of his book sent to Sir John Pringle, Dr. Priestley and other friends. His visit from the Emperor [of Austria] who expressed his regret at not having seen Franklin in Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Understood that there was a letter for him from America which Franklin kindly promised to forward; gives address.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends translation of Amsterdam's proposal. His intention to write to Congress concerning the difficulties in which his faithful services to the United States have involved him.
(Partly in French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the birth of a daughter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Goes on board in an hour. Hears that Franklin has expressed a desire to withdraw from business; in case his resignation should be accepted, will use any influence in his power to insure its being attended with every mark of honor and consideration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has given the packet to Col. Laurens and received the postage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending Mr. Gleiss, who was acquainted with Franklin in London and wishes to consult him on scientific matters.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Wendorp, D. and Heyliger, T. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning their vessel supposed to have been retaken from the English by an American privateer and carried into Morlaix.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the officers of the frigate "Pallas" who have abused his credit; asking redress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that bills lately remitted for payment to Mr. Isaac Hazlehurst by the Hon. Robert Morris be accepted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received his letter and the enclosed engravings. Thanks Franklin for his offer to give him fuller explanations. Intends to have a model of the stove made to introduce its use in ordinary kitchens.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received as a boarder a destitute young man called William. Williams who claims to be Franklin's nephew; desires advice in the matter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commanded the "General Washington" when she was captured by the "Culloden"; his present unfortunate situation in an English prison; begs that fifty pounds be sent him on account.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commanded the "Hancock"; begs for a small remittance. American prisoners, worn out by their long confinement, daily enter the English service; their allowance scarcely provides for one meal a day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a young man to Franklin who is seeking employment as a secretary. Intends to go to see Franklin before his departure.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter to be delivered to Mr. Laurens's oldest son then in France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to serve in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [John] Thayer has asked for an introduction; is glad of this opportunity to express her appreciation of her Uncle's kindness to Mr. Collas during his imprisonment in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Capt. Bennet of the "Franklin" has remitted him the money from the sale of the six ransoms.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ready to put to sea in a few days; would be honored by any commands from Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning Franklin's desire to retire from his present important station; suggests the appointment of a Secretary of Legation; qualifications of Franklin's grandson for such a position.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 41; Bigelow, VII, 251).

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conti, Louis-François-Joseph de Bourbon, comte de la Marche and prince de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring passports for the grooms who go to England to purchase dogs.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His promise to examine the accounts of the frigate "Alliance," and advise him upon the subject.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to a geographical and historical dictionary he is going to publish and asking Franklin to suscribe to it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appeals to Franklin for assistance to pay his board and lodging whilst waiting for a vessel to take him to America. Will repay the money on his arrival or give a note on his partner Charles Washington of Fredericksburg, Va.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Droüart, Charles-François-Robert (?), seigneur de Lezey, chevalier. Vic

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His letters to his son [Henry Dieudonné Drouart] in Philadelphia seem to miscarry; begs that they may be sent under cover to Franklin's son-in-law [Richard Bache], to whom his son is known. Present occupation unworthy of his birth and lineage.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduces Mr. Cornelius Ray.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His capture by the English; is an American by birth; desires his release.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of his son, Surgeon on the Letter of Marque, "De Graaff," taken at St. Eustatius and sent to England; encloses a letter of credit for his son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His promise to recommend him to Congress to fill the chair of Professor of Anatomy; Dr. Chauvet [Abraham Chovet] his only rival.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commission of Benjamin Franklin, John Jay, Henry Laurens, Thomas Jefferson and John Adams to negotiate a treaty of peace with Great Britain.
(Copy.)

did.physdesc: D.S. Sam[uel] Huntington President, and Sealed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commission of Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, John Jay, Henry Laurens and Thomas Jefferson to accept the mediation of the Emperor of Germany and the Empress of Russia.
(In triplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His cousin, Mr. Samuel Hartley, thinks of going to Paris; would like to come himself, provided the French Ministry consent; as a former member of Parliament and an honorable man, desires to do nothing in secret. Conciliatory bill moved by his brother in the House of Commons, in the same form as his own of the year before.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has once more obtained his liberty; hopes for a speedy passage to America.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergennes, Charles Gravier, comte de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Knows nothing of the disposition Mr. [John] Laurens has made of the six millions which the King granted to Congress; suggests that M. de Veimerange might be able to inform Franklin as to these matters; the destination of the funds is also a matter of which he is completely ignorant.
(In French. Letter press copy in duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a copy of a letter from Col. Laurens concerning the advisability of using the frigate "South Carolina" to convey to America part of the specie destined for the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Communicating instructions for the negotiation of peace.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 46; Bigelow, VII, 256).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a retired Captain in the German army and wishes to serve in America provided he receives a higher rank and the continuation of his German pension.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recounts the services he rendered to the United States since 1777 in landing a rich cargo in Charlestown and saving several American vessels from capture by English cruisers. Requests Franklin to give him a testimonial for Marquis de Castries similar to the one he previously gave him for M. de Sartine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His plans for returning to America. Miseries of American prisoners in England; hunger forces them into the English service. If the accounts of Mr. Digges be true, thinks him one of the worst of men.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. George Harrison, of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter which they have just received from Antwerp.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will be a great pleasure for him to meet such a lady, but would have been pleased in any case to wait on Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will bring the instrument mentioned, the following Sunday if convenient.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending his nephew and M. Larendoutte who were officers on the ship "Marquis de la Fayette" which was captured by British cruisers while bound for Philadelphia with a cargo of supplies for Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a despatch from America just received in his own despatches.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assures him of their health and the continuance of their affection, Popularity of the French officers; determination of the French to take New York; reason why the American officers declined to give them advice as to the transportation of their baggage. Efforts made by Franklin's sister [Mecom] to obtain the sermon he worte for; fears it was lost in the hurry of the wedding.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: States the condition upon which he will receive Mr.Young into his household and instruct him in the French tongue.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His son, William Davies, a prisoner in England; begs that Franklin will allow him $100 for which bills will be duly honored.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advisable to wait a few days to sail with a Dutch squadron destined as a convoy to the Baltic. The loss of the "Marquis de la Fayette" renders every precaution necessary to prevent a further disappointment in supplies. Any commands of Franklin's will be faithfully attended to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Digges's guilt well-established; subscription for the relief of the prisoners exhausted; if there is any cash to spare begs that it be forwarded, as there are five hundred of these unfortunates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The troubles of Capt. [Joseph] Conkling with his brig the "Whim" and her cargo of tobacco. The need of a consul at La Rochelle; desires the post.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The capture of their ship "Elégante" by the English frigate "Emerald," through treachery of the militia of the country; indemnification accorded by Congress; new laws passed which would affect the value of said indemnity; desires Franklin's intervention.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard of the capture of the "Marquis de la Fayette"; loss to America of this much-needed clothing; offers a quantity of cloth and other furniture, to be shipped at Franklin's command.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account with Benjamin Franklin from 1777, June 12, to 1781, July 1.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Services rendered to one William Williams purporting to be Franklin's nephew; desires reimbursement.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His determination to arrest the money now in M. Fizeaux's hands; it was committed to his (Jackson's) charge for a special purpose and he is accountable; Franklin cannot have the disposal of the money, as it was obtained by Col. Laurens, appointed Special Minister for that purpose; entreats the repeal of Franklin's orders to M. Fizeaux, which detains the ship and supplies so much needed in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obliged in conformity to Col. Laurens's instructions, to retain the money confided to his care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for permission to return to Lille. Enumerates goods he will carry in the sloop "Lively."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to enter the service of the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the French crew of the "Revenge"; certain they have no just cause for complaint; they were paid their shares in spite of being the worst of mariners and of little service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remonstrating against the detention of Commodore Gillon's vessel, which is to carry the sorley-needed supplies to America; in case Franklin refuses to withdraw his orders to M. Fizeaux, will be obliged to solicit the interference of Court and to produce Col. Laurens's instructions to him and his despatches to Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a copy [1p.] of the declaration of the French Ambassador, M. de la Vauguyon, announcing a suspension of the decree against Holland until August 1st. Leaving immediately for Rotterdam; will go from thense to Paris, according to Franklin's desire.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: According to Franklin's directions, M. Auer wrote in regard to some money in Germantown, Pennsylvania, due a widow in his parish, but has received no response; desires further advice.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has left her native land in search of peace; not in Mr. Cochran's power at present to remit money for her child's schooling; Mr. Cochran among the prisoners sent from Charlestown to St. Augustine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to let his servant take the trunks left at Passy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the death of his father-in-law, the Marquis de Courtanvaux.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends letters addressed to Mr. Moses Young to Franklin's care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin if possible to obtain intelligence from London concerning his appeal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Samuel Powel Griffitts, his great nephew, who has studied physic under Dr. Kuhn of Philadelphia and taken his degree with honor; a voyage to England being difficult at this juncture, the young man will visit the hospitals in France; will be most grateful for any kindness shown him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Capt. [Bennet] Negus of the "Franklin" whose conduct during his late cruise deserves much praise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Samuel [Powel] Griffitts; will be most grateful for any kindness shown his kinsman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Grateful for interest shown in his advancement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The united fleet near Cadiz. Rumor of the capture of Pensacola; rejoicing on the part of the King; celebrations in which Mr. Jay will take part; all this very flattering to [Don Joseph] Galvez who has the honor of this enterprise and to his nephew [Bernard Galvez] who had the glory of executing it. Military affairs in America; advantage seems to be with the Unites States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Married to a native of Newbury, Mass, who has been taken prisoner; left with two small children; begs Franklin to procure her a situation as housekeeper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has a predilection for military life. His parents enlisted him as a volunteer in the Swiss Guard at Paris. Asks Franklin to recommend him to be promoted to be an officer in the Swiss Guard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to forward a sum of money to her son, serving in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the acceptance of a bill, probably found on some ship taken by the English.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote him by the unfortunate President Laurens, enclosing some of his labors in the cause; his chief disappointment in the loss of his squibs was that they would probably have given Franklin cause for laughter -- a most wholesome exercise. Will not discuss the question of Franklin's friends and enemies; to be without the latter is to be of no consequence in the world; his own love and esteem for Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reason why his letters have declined in number; recommends certain extra precautions to prevent his letters being opened. Enclosures for Congress and Mr. [William] Carmichael.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Veillard will be discharged with the other passengers of the "Marquis de la Fayette"; they will all be furnished with papers and permits to pursue any route they judge proper; has furnished Mr. Veillard with a letter of credit. Further trickeries of Digges brought to light.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to embark shortly for Philadelphia; will take charge of any letters for Franklin or Mr. Williams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives carpenter's estimate and address.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
