scopecontent.p: Captured a brig which he suspects of being commissioned against the United States; wishes to know if Franklin ever granted a pass to a certain Benjamin Joy in command of said brig. Expects to sail in four or five weeks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter to be forwarded to his cousin, Mr. Martin, in Boston.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inventor of a machine, warranted to destroy the rock of Gibraltar, and of many others which will secure victory to the American cause; explains his inventions.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Five American officers of vessels who have escaped from Forton Prison in England appeal for assistance and for instructions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his friend, Mr. Robert Young, to whom he is indebted for counteracting the influence of his enemies in the Island of Grenada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for reimbursement for supplies furnished to American prisoners.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sums expended for the relief of American prisoners, among others, a Mr. Macnamara, lieutenant of artillery in the service of the State of Maryland, who made his escape from Mill Prison.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Penet, D'Acosta frères and Cie. Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for news of a packet of important letters directed to Mr. Mazzei and recommended to Franklin's care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that his commission be transmitted; his ship ready to be launched.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Pownall, Thomas and Vaughan, Benjamin. London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received Franklin's letter, also one from Lewis Evans's daughter Amelia Barey, desiring some remittance from the sale of the maps and topographical descriptions of America; fears his reply miscarried, wherein he advised her to apply to Mr. Almon; introducing his friend Mr. Hobart. Wishes to God he and Franklin could meet; thinks together they might do something to arrest the ruin which hangs over both countries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin some papers read at the last meeting of the Royal Society of Medicine, and a printed report on the burial of the dead in the Island of Malta. Thanks him for assisting at the Society's public meetings.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to be instructed in the art of making printers' ink; desires to know the process employed in England by which maps are printed on pocket handkerchiefs, London in red on one side and Paris in blue on the other.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses list of all accepted bills since his last account. Hopes the rumor that the ship is to sail in a few days will prove true.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been ill several days and unable to work on his [musical] instruments; hopes to have it completed in a week.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends 600 livres which Franklin has promised to forward to Madame Thomassin's son, an officer in the French troops stationed in Rhode Island.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses letter to be forwarded to Gen. [John Peter Gabriel] Muhlenberg at Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that all possible kindness and protection be shown an American of French origin, M. Crevecoeur, the son of an old friend of hers and of her husband; he has been many years in America and has come over to visit his family; has lost most of his property in the present war. Hopes to see again at Sannois her dear Doctor for whom she has the greatest respect and admiration.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the third volume of the works of [Geatano] Filangieri, with a letter from the author.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the acceptance of bills drawn to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appeal from fifteen escaped prisoners claiming to be Americans who are destitute and who beg for relief.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging his kind offices on behalf of Mr. [Matthew] Ridley, who is about to return to France on private affairs, as well as on matters concerning the State of Maryland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter to be forwarded to his brother, Inspector-General of the United States army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearer, Capt. William Kennedy, of Baltimore, has come to London to remove some property from there to the Middle States; Resolve passed by Congress forbidding this after November 1st; begs for Franklin's intervention as they cannot possibly arrange the affair before the expiration of that time.
A.E. by Franklin, "refused."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ignorant what kind of treatment an American in the French service should expect, when taken prisoner by the English; think that Capt. Christopher Codner, late commander of privateer "The American Union," was given treatment unworthy of a civilized nation; beg Franklin to procure his exchange; they have laid his case before the Marquis de Castries, Minister of Marine; transcribe three of Capt. Codner's letters describing his treatment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In regard to some papers of importance lately received from the Government of Virginia; instructed by Government to avail himself of Franklin's information and advice; hopes he will excuse the liberty he has taken.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Knows of nothing which should detain Commodore Gillon from setting sail.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: d'Aguesseau, Marquis Henri Cardin Jean Baptiste. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The case of Alexander against the Bank of England ready to be heard; M. d'Aguesseau requested to summon a Committee to judge the affair.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a subscription.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for John Mayo which he begs may be delivered.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assurance from M. d'Aguesseau that Mr. Alexander's affair will be tried the following week. Asking his kind interest for the enclosed memoir.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends despatches just received under cover of Robert Morris, Esq., of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding certain letters to Mrs. Strange under Franklin's care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charged by the Royal Society of Medicine to send him tickets for the next public meeting; the Society hope that Franklin will give them the honor and encouragement of his presence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the paper by Mr. [Alexander] Small on the method of ventilating the interior of hospitals, read before the Royal Society of Medicine.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VI, 437).

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergennes, Charles Gravier, comte de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning certain financial offers made by the Minister on the part of the King with a view of helping America out of her most pressing difficulties.
(Letter press copy. In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Holland's attitude towards America; fair prospect of obtaining a loan for the United States. M. De Linden's famous letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives dates of his letters to the Comte de Vergennes concerning the Peace Commission; thinks the new one will be as useless as the old, and that Britain will never think of peace till every British soldier is killed or captured; quotes from the Empress of Russia's proclamation regarding the Peace Commission to be held at Vienna. Weary of round-about and endless negotiations; thinks the Dutch have at last discovered the only effective method: fighting the British ships until the signal of distress is raised; if he ever did any good since he was born, it was in setting in motion the old Batavian spirit of the Dutch. Has no belief in the Peace Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Franklin on his great qualities; America's noble exertions to be seen in the free trade granted to Ireland; prophesies success to America. Is an Irish Catholic priest, taken prisoner on his passage home from England; is now on parole; if he can obtain his liberty desires to go to America. Sends Franklin a little book as a part of his small endeavors to be of use to his fellow creatures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering his services as printer.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has befriended five Americans, who escaped from English prisons; thinks that an agent should be appointed for such purpose; will gladly perform this office without fee, if Franklin believes him capable; refers him to the Comte d'Houdetot and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to borrow 1,500 livres; only extreme necessity forces him to ask such a favor; has ample security.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Much worried at the silence of Mr. Wharton, of Phila., with whom Mr. Coffyn, Dr. Bancroft and himself had engaged in a mercantile speculation. Delighted that the Americans beat a superior English force; thinks it shameful that the King of England should bestow a ribbon upon Admiral [Peter] Parker, who was obliged to retreat before the Dutch. Has published a new treatise in Holland on the manner of respirating and purifying air.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [John] Adams has been ill with fever for three weeks and is confined to his bed and unable to write; desires him to acquaint Franklin with the British Government's attempts to make secret contracts with the Americans for masts, yards and howsprits; for these they offer great prices; thinks the French Court should be asked whether they would have any objection to Congress laying an embargo on the exportation of these articles.
(Copy.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Difficulties encountered in procuring Commodore Gillon's signature, in order that the goods purchased by Col. Laurens might be shipped to America; desires his advice and directions as to future proceedings.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Dumesnil de St. Pierre, Henriette. Isigny

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Trouble taken by Franklin in ascertaining the circumstances of M. [John Lewis Dumesnil] de St. Pierre's death; has just received from Charleston all the necessary papers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received with joy Franklin's response in regard to the poor widow, Mme. Hōcklerin and her children; has followed his advice, and written to Mr. Richard Bache of Philadelphia. Begs that the enclosed letters may be forwarded.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Greatly pleased at Franklin's acceptance of her invitation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commissioned officer on board the "Confederacy" when she was captured by the English; has been ill ever since landing in France; begs that a place be found for him on board a man-of-war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received orders from M. de Castries to embark for further service in America. Asks for news of Mr. Searle.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transcribes letter written July 30th. Concerning the capture of their ship "Elégante," and the indemnification promised them by Congress; desires Franklin's assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Trumbull had been discharged. At New Prison was refused admission to Mr. Gouverneur without an order from Mr. Knox, Lord Geo. Germain's Secretary. Encloses copies of his correspondence with Mr. Knox (1p.). Had no trouble in seeing Mr. Curson who thanks Franklin for his attention but neither he nor Mr. Gouverneur are in need of funds at present. Mr. Witherspoon discharged and soon to leave the country. Hopes for a speedy exchange of prisoners; some of the unfortunates have been three years in confinement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his cousin who was taken prisoner at Savannah and who desires to see further service in the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards letters received under cover from Robert Morris, Esq.; the messenger can be trusted in case Franklin wishes to send despatches by the "Delaware" or "Anne."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of money difficulties with a M. Dotun Le Sage; because of being a stranger, is obliged to settle with the villain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing three letters which have just arrived by way of London.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the Gazette; had already heard through M. le Chevalier de la Luzerne that the boasting of Mr. Cornwallis was of the same order as that of Admiral Rodney. In regard to the papers relating to passports, he supposes Franklin wishes him to lay them before the Peace Conference; thinks Mr. Robert Morris's letter should be communicated.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commodore Gillon owes them a large sum of money; according to Franklin's orders, went to M. Amelot who will await them the next day at twelve o'clock; begs that Franklin will have the goodness to be present while their sad situation is being explained. Adjoins memorial (4p.) concerning the orders taken for the clothing and equipment of the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to visit his paper manufactory.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [John] Adams convalescing from a severe illness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires advice respecting the education of her son who may be placed in a school near Paris. Mr. and Mrs. [Richard] Bache and family were with them in July.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding certain publications; Capt. [Jonathan] Carver's volume most interesting, treating of a country destined to form the hemisphere of freedom. Dr. Fothergill's works to be published in three volumes or one large quarto; anxious for any remarks of anectodes of their late amiable friend which Franklin may care to send him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if it is true that American manufactories have been established at Nantes and other parts of France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards the enclosed letters, as it is safer to transmit them through Franklin's hands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a note of two books and desires that three complete sets be purchased on the Public Account and sent to him by three different conveyances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a complaint lodged against Mr.[David Salisbury] Franks that he left Cadiz without paying for his passage; this accusation unjust as Mr. Robert Morris engaged to pay the passage money in question.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Stephen Willson lately arrived from America.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: V. and P. French and Nephew. Bordeaux

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter for Mr. James Price, an American of distinction, lately arrived at l'Orient; remittances received for him despatched to their banker at Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his favor of the 11th inst. in regard to the suspension requested by Messrs. Lamarque and Fabre; the account to be laid before the King with the details kindly entered into by Franklin, as to the cause of the difficulty.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard with infinite satisfaction of Congress's refusal to accept Franklin's resignation, as well as the news of his appointment as a Peace Commissioner. Salary allowed him by Congress liberal but his expenses are numerous. Reasons why he has little opinion of the loan in Holland. Glad that the Court of France has engaged to replace the cargo of the "Marquis de la Fayette"; thinks the Americans have a way of demanding things as a right that they should solicit as a favor; cites Mr. Laurens as an example of this. Will send the memoirs of the Economical Society by first opportunity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to wait upon Franklin on account of preparations for his departure; asks for introductions to Mr. Williams and to French merchants at Nantes; desires a passport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intelligence he collected while travelling through England; made his escape from a guard-ship in Plymouth where he had been detained a prisoner with Col. William Richardson. Account of the ships in the harbor at Plymouth and their destination. English papers speak of sending to America four regiments of infantry and one of horse; a mystery where they are to get them.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafreté, Angélique-Michéle-Rosalie Jogues de Martinville. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The name of the person she recommended to Franklin for the position of Consul is M. Galart des Graux. Announces her intention of making a little trip into Normandy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning her son who served in the American navy for seven years and has only just returned.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a bill of exchange drawn on Franklin by Mr. Nixon; greatly impressed with Franklin's generosity; offers to advance the money to Mr. Nixon.
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. Obliged to him but the bill is paid.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The discharge of Major [William] Cowley, taken by the "Black Princess" and carried to Cherbourg. Board of Sick and Hurt agree to release Captain Manley in exchage. Number of prisoners released from Spain, of whom the Board takes no account. Prisons in England much crowded; upwards of seven hundred in confinement.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [John] Adams still unable to attend to business; their share has been duly attended to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bidding good-bye to Franklin on her departure for a long journey.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a package and two letters which he had received for Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his safe arrival.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know the fate of Mr. Pownall's letter to Mr. Bowdoin and Dr. Cooper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's kindness in writing to the Minister on their behalf.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Suggesting a plan to prevent the horrid consequences of fire in opera and play-houses. Promises to send drawings and further details; efficacy of a fire-screen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommended to Franklin by the Comtesse d'Houdetot. Has been put in possession of the wherry in which the five Americans came over; sincerely sorry for poor Colonel [William] Palfrey; hopes that his successor will be equally capable.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reports Mr. Gillon's violation of his contract and complains of the treatment accorded him and his companions by the former.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is stopping at a country seat 30 leagues from Paris on her journey to Nice for her health. Describes the country and its beautiful scenery. Postscript by M. Pagin, a friend of Dr. Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a letter from America from Baron de Steuben; takes the liberty of sending his answer to Franklin's care.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him certain letters destined for America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the bill of exchange on M. de Chaumont which he has had protested.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a book and a letter from Gov. Pownall.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know if there is room in the service for more Frenchmen, who can furnish the best certificates and who are persons of family.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Gibbs, who desires to obtain Franklin's counsel in France, where he expects to spend some years; he is a son of Judge Gibbs and a grandson of Secretary [Josiah] Willard of whom he is a worthy descendant.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The vessel from New Haven bringing the accompanying packet brought also of hopes being high in America, on account of the expected arrival of M. de Grasse on that coast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the difference with [Major William] Jackson and [Col. John] Laurens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His illness. Concerning the Commission appointed to negotiate peace; question of Mr. [Thomas] Jefferson accepting the trust; possible answer of the British to the articles which will serve as basis.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 81; Bigelow, VII, 299).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a commission for a fast-sailing brig under the command of Capt. James Tucker, purchased by some American seamen and officers lately arrived from England; intends to arm her as a letter of marque and put on board a small cargo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed that Franklin has received bills of exchange drawn upon her; refuses to pay them unless Fanklin and his grandson consent to dine with her the following day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bitterly disappointed at being refused permission to enter the service of America; gave up his post in service of the Emperor and made this long journey, all in vain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Capt. William Gibbons, whose ship was taken by the English on the voyage from Amsterdam to Boston; has just arrived from England and desires to consult Franklin on the best means of returning to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is disappointed at not having heard from Franklin and her friends at Passy. Leaving for Avignon in a few days.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering a new method of keeping copying paper damped.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends his allegory in honor of the late Maria Theresa; his daughter finds great pleasure in Franklin's society.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for advice and assistance in the construction of her fire-place.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his kindness to him during his stay in Paris. Coolness with which science is courted in Leipsic; inferiority of their schools to those in Paris; in no way superior to the young seminary which owes its birth to Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Money due them. Amount and quality of tea forwarded. Desires Franklin's attention to Capt. Bell's request. Concerning the privateer, "Buccaneer," commanded by Capt [Hoysted] Hacker; importance of his not releasing his prisoners; thinks a few lines from Franklin would be efficacious.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the fulfilment of his contract and the payment of the debts of the State of South Carolina.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reasons which have determined him to educate his two elder sons, Robert and Thomas, in Europe; the bearer, Matthew Ridley, Esq., accompanies them to France and will see them placed at school in Geneva, if Franklin approves this choice; his intention to give them a liberal education. His veneration for Franklin's abilities and character must be his apology for drawing his attention from more important concerns; begs that he will assist Mr.Ridley with his good advice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Much fatigued by the vehicle in which he travelled from Paris. Inquiries he made concerning Major Frank's whereabouts. Expects to continue his journey in the morning; the boatmen's demands very extravagant. Wants Franklin to make his excuses to Mr. and Miss Channing for not taking leave of them; knocked several times at their door without success.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written to Calais and to England for a copy of the work spoken of by Franklin. Sets out for Brussels tomorrow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing her son; hopes to wait on Franklin herself in a few days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his journey from Orleans; his hospitable reception; Mme. de Chaumont and her children in good health; they depend on a visit from Franklin at Christmas; Mr. de Chaumont much beloved in that part of the world; all the family send their love and the beautiful Mme. Foucault accompanies hers with an English kiss.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a poor family called Beer who have come to Amsterdam with recommendations from Mr. Coffyn and Dr. Franklin; will do his best to get the father work of some kind. Relief he has furnished for a year past to American prisoners; no public money in his hands; cannot keep it up out of his own pocket; suggests other ways of continuing such a laudable work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is once more at liberty and hopes in a few days to repay his loan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Renewing his application for a commission for the brig, "Sally," Capt. James Tucker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of St. Jean, whose father M. de Crevecoeur is one of her oldest friends; begs Franklin to assist him in his desire to serve the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her health is beginning to improve. Promises to write by turns to Franklin and Le Veillard. Has seen in the harbor a vessel called the "Comte d'Estaing" which was for sale.
Postscript by M. Brillon. Hopes much from their stay at Nice, reputed to have the best climate in Southern France or Italy.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, October, 1906, 38.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a pamplet by a former friend of Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has had an expensive law-suit which must be determined in her favor next fall; desires Franklin to assist her with £20

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires a certain kind of paper for a little volume which he is at present printing; hopes to offer Franklin a copy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statement of account with the United States from May 16 to October 22, 1781.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for information concerning the duties and powers of a Peace Commissioner. Discusses demand made by Prince de Galitzin. Acknowledges Franklin's medical advice. Desires to know what disposition is to be made of the Continental goods left by Gillon and detained for the freight; from first to last was never consulted in the business; believes Col. Laurens has been imposed upon and that Gillon has Violated his contract with him; urges Franklin to send [Major William] Jackson to Amsterdam to finish the business, which has been cruelly mismanaged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Boyetet, Spanish Consul-General for France, who will carry Franklin certain letters and papers; Mr.Boyetet's long residence in Spain; his knowledge of public affairs and the great assistance and kindness he has received from him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking on behalf of M. de Chalut, Farmer-General, that Franklin dine with him on the 26th.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know M. de Chaumont's decision in regard to paying the bill of exchange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their good friend desires Franklin to dine with her the next day before going to Notre Dame for Te Deum.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Testifying to Gillon's good character.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Bohlen, Anna Sophia Susanna de (née Franklin)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Claims to be Franklin's great niece through her father' father, John Franklin; has lost all her relatives; would like to come to Paris, but her means too narrow to permit of it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of August 6th. Explanation of how his account was reported to have been mixed up with Mr. [F.M.] Dana's. Question of his receiving a salary from the French Court; if this is refused him and Congress can remit him nothing, hopes at least he will be granted a free passage on one of the first frigates of war sent to America; reasons why it would go ill with him, were he taken prisoner by the English; would infinitely rather lie in the tower at Newgate than dishonor the United States by begging or borrowing the means for his subsistence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Since, recommending the young man to Franklin, has heard some very disagreeable things about him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Surgeon on the brig, "Wexford"; captured by His Majesty's frigate "Recovery"; destitute of money and friends; offers to draw a bill on Samuel Huntington for whatever Franklin will advance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ships which the "South Carolina" was to have taken under her convoy; advises that they be purchased and sent to America where their sale will far out-weigh the cost; urges that [Major William] Jackson be sent to Amsterdam to conduct the business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires the honor of a letter for Geneva, as there is a probability of her leaving shortly for that place.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In his power to obtain a loan of 600,000 livres (tournois) for the use of the Commonwealth of Virginia, if Franklin will legalize his bonds for the State.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Major Cowley's release. Proposition made by the Board of Sick and Hurt as regards the exchange of prisoners; the last remittance used up; begs for a further supply.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Without money or credit they are obliged to stay in France until they can get some remittance from America; Mr. Wharton and his friends, though so heavily in their debt, do nothing to relieve them; report of Mr. Wharton being killed. Possibility of selling a piece of property in Baltimore has raised their spirits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Bory, who will transmit Franklin the bond, duly executed, for the commission of the brig, "Mariana." Hopes soon to see the Southern States freed from the rapacious ravages of a cruel enemy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Justifying the conduct of J[ohn] S[c]haffer towards himself.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a description (3p.) of a medal to be struck off in commemoration of the birth of the Dauphin; it will be bestowed as a mark of special merit upon the pupils of a certain military school; begs Franklin's influence with the Minister in support of the plan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring him to witness several of his experiments, which are based upon Franklin's learned works.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him two pairs of worsted stockings from which to take his choice. Question of the payments to Mr. Deane by Messrs. Strablborn and Wolff of St. Petersburg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning certain duties demanded by the Farmers-General; considers them unjust and absurd. Account of a slanderer in Nantes who accuses Franklin of encouraging Capt. [John] Folger in carrying on an illicit trade with the enemy; gives Franklin this opportunity of denying it, if he thinks it worth his notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a letter for Chevalier de la Luzerne and requests Franklin to forward it.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Faculty of the Royal College. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to the opening of the session.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announces the defeat of the British on Chesapeake Bay; also that Cornwallis had proposed terms of capitulation.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The disposition of the Continental goods left by Gillon, and detained for the freight; advises Franklin to buy the ships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In accordance with enclosed Resolve of Congress (2p.) has signed certain Loan Office bills of exchange.
(2 copies.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sailed from Philadelphia in the "Franklin"; captured by the English; escaped from prison with his two principal officers and seven of his men; refused help to get to L'Orient or Nantes; applies to Franklin. News from America; French fleet's safe arrival in the Chesapeake; Gen. Washington's junction with the Marquis de la Fayette; Cornwallis's difficult position; Arnold's burning of New London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received no answer to request for passport for their family; at present her uncle's ill health has put an end to their plan of going to England. Transcribes part of a letter received from a near friend in London, describing the cruel imprisonment of her father; thinks it a sad reflection on America that one of her Ambassadors should, in his prison, want for the common necessaries of life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing letters from America; has just arrived by the ship "St. James"; sends a rough draught of the situation of the French and American armies surrounding Lord Cornwallis; opinion of some officers that he will be forced to surrender in about six weeks. Various reports concerning an action between Gen. [Nathanael] Greene and Col. [Alexander] Stuart, about sixty miles from Charleston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complimenting him on his love of truth, and the greatness of his soul.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Master [Benjamin Franklin] Bache in good health; had the pleasure of seeing Madame Cramer; believes Geneva to be a very proper place for education; sure that their sons will receive every wished-for improvement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know if Franklin received a letter from one of their friends in Königsberg.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his favor of the 7th inst. by Mr. [George] Fox, to whom he promises to show every possible civility. His son embarked for Salem in a privateer. Concerning the Continental goods detained for freight at Amsterdam; discusses the best means of obtaining possession of the goods and the safest way of conveying them to America. His letters to Franklin have been opened in spite of being sent in care of Fizeaux and Grand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the happy event, which prepares the way for Independence; Franklin's part in this memorable revolution; enthusiasm of the French at this turn of affairs. Desires an interview on an important subject.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: When captured bore the rank of midshipman on the frigate "Confederacy"; his distressing situation; encloses a set of bills (1p.) drawn on Thaddeus Burr at Fairfield, Conn.; begs Franklin to remit him in part their value.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the good news. Their dear Dowager's [Duchesse de Deux-Ponts] son, William [Count de Deux-Ponts], has arrived on the frigate "Andromache"; his distinguished conduct at the siege of York; reception of the great news by M. le Comte de Maurepas.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the surrender of Cornwallis and his army. Ask leave to dine with Franklin on Sunday to celebrate the event.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for money due her from the American vessel "Le Capitaine Jaune."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Charles Traverse; sends two books; should they meet with Franklin's approval, his endorsement would be highly flattering to the authors. Mr. Del Campo's dangerous illness retards everything; their dependence, public and personal, is on Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the request of young M. Johonnot, sends the enclosed prospectus (1p.) of the pension at Ecully; the dear child recommended to his care by the Abbés Chalut and Arnoux; believes he will receive a better education at the above school than at Geneva.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to forward the enclosed, which will be handed to him by a Mr. [Robert] Pigott, a friend to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of Capt. John Lander[s] and Lieut. [Robert] Wil(l)cocks, American subjects, confined for no apparent reason by order of the General-Commissary of the Navy; their miserable situation without comforts or any knowledge of the French language; entreats their release. Congratulates Franklin on the good news from America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brought with him, from Philadelphia, numerous letters giving an account of his services during the last five years; captured on his way to France and obliged to destroy everything but his recommendation from Congress to the Ministers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Hopkins, Mr. Gibbs and Mr. Hoops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulate him on the news of the surrender of Cornwallis. Will set out for Nantes to-morrow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His relationship by marriage to Mr. Laurens; that gentleman's present imprisonment; no provision made for his support; naturally declines pecuniary assistance offered him. Account of Mrs. Laurens's death at Lisle and her bequests to her maid and child; magistrates have refused to suffer the operation of her will, till the Colonel's pleasure in known; has the child with him at present, as well as Mr. H. Laurens, a fine spirited, honorable young man; knows Franklin will do what is right.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received no answer to any of his letters since leaving Paris; M. Penet writes that he delivered the papers to Dr. Franklin and asked for M. Mazzei's address in order to send him the money on account of the State of Virginia; does not know if this is true; begs to be enlightened on this point.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging an invitation to dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolution giving permission to Marquis de la Fayette to return to France and directing the Ministers of the United States to confer with him relative to the situation in America.
(Attested copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Five Manchester manufacturers of cotton and other fabrics make a proposal to go to the United States with their families and establish factories, if granted certain conditions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter to Baron Steuben.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on America's decisive successes; enthusiasm at Bordeaux not yet subsided; hopes to set on foot two or three expeditions in virtue of the change the news has made.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing a merchant of Nantes who has been defrauded by M. Penet, Agent-General for the State of Virginia; begs Franklin to see justice done.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to Franklin from his brother Masons of the Lodge to attend a Te Deum with them on the following day, and be present afterwards at a reception, discourse, banquet and concert at the Royal Lodge.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the surrender of Cornwallis; Franklin the rocky base of this happy revolution, against which tyranny will one day shatter itself.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his promise to dine with her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for his brother in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the plans of the periodical paper he is preparing to publish; came to Paris to procure its admission in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reflections on her travels and their influence on her mind and character. Narration of a trip on sea in a fishing boat to visit a Spanish frigate which had put into Villefranche. Encloses a memorandum by M. Breton on the possibilities of trade between Marseilles and the United States. Recommends M. Breton as a correspondent or agent at Marseilles in case the United States needs one.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposed Treaty of Alliance between France, Holland and the United States. Congratulations on the surrender of Cornwallis. Disposition of the Continental goods.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 95).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires on what day Franklin has promised to dine at Mme. de St. Wast's.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a memoir by Mr. Villiam, to obtain the commission of Captain on his return to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The loss of two bills drawn on Franklin; stops payment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The treatment of Mr. [Henry] Laurens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes the late glorious event will soon bring peace; their dear friend [the Dowager Duchesse de Deux-Ponts] is still supremely happy; her son has arrived in good health, a trifle brown, but only from the shadow of the laurels he carries.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just arrived from America; sends three packets entrusted to his care by General Washington; all impatience to see Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Capt. All, who rejoiced at the opportunity to confound malicious tongues, sends a newspaper showing the inhuman conduct of Lord Rawdon, now a prisoner in Paris; thinks the French ought to know that a butcher he is.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation to dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Incoherent remarks about a French regiment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their excellent "Dowager" [Duchesse de Deux-Ponts] desires Franklin to dine with her on Saturday; he will meet various persons who respect and love him, and above all, the brave Count William, who will talk to him of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Personages who have spoken in his favor; all of the opinion that if Franklin endorses their request, it will go through; honors conferred upon him by Congress, and wounds received in their service justify his demands.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a copy of Gen. Washington's letter, as well as any details of Cornwallis's surrender. Anticipate meeting Franklin at dinner the following Saturday at M. de Chalut's; if Franklin can persuade Dr. Bancroft to be of the party, it will give them all great pleasure.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives his opening lecture the following day at eleven; invites Franklin to be present.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has contracted for a small brig the. "Yorktown" to be sent off with all despatch to Philadelphia; desires a passport for her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the successes of the United States. Will forward Dr. Priestley's new volume to the Duc de la Rochefoucauld.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Franklin, William Temple. Chateau de Chaumont

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His delay in returning to Paris due to the impossiblity of procuring a place in any of the public conveyances for Paris; may be obliged to go to the expense of a carbriolet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Anxious to wait upon him with Mme. Le Roy to congratulate him on the happy event at York.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his services in the Ameican army, his entering into her navy and his capture by the English; the uncommon distress experienced by prisoners in England; begs Franklin to procure his exchange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the memoir which Franklin promised to remit to the Marquis de Ségur; M. le Duc D'ayen and le Prince de Poix join with him in begging Franklin's acquiescence to his demands.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of their imprisonment in England, their exchange, and arrival in France; lies told about them by the French officers; their present miserable confinement; ignorant of their crime; beg Franklin to release them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on the successes of the American arms; desire him to celebrate the event by dining with them on the 3d, in company with Mesdames des Deux Ponts and M. le Comte Guillaume.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discusses the disposition of the Continental goods detained at Amsterdam. Much pleased with Franklin's reflections on the glorious news; few military plans ever better laid or executed; believes in a land war America could defend herself against the world. Asks whereabouts of the Comte de Grasse. Concerning the distressing situation of Mr. Laurens; has ventured to promise £100 for him; pathetic letter received from his daughter; referred her to Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter for his son, General von Steuben; report is current that both feet of the General have been shot off. Is this true?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies again to Franklin to obtain the money due her from the ship "Le Capitaine Jaune."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Five years' service in the American cause; is in the direst need of every necessity; begs for assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Embarked as ship's doctor on a vessel bound for St. Domingo; captured by the English; imprisoned at Liverpool; finally released on condition of leaving the country; desires Franklin to assist him to America.
(In Latin.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations as a loyal American and a good Frenchman on Gen. Washington's victory in Virginia. The five Americans who escaped from England the summer before have been happily embarked at Nantes for Newburyport, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the packet sent him by Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two months ago they returned the print of the Queen of Hungary's tomb; beg that they may be reassured as to Franklin's health.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes Franklin's opinion of l'Abbé Raynal's History of the American Revolution; desires to translate it into German if it is written with intelligence and impartiality. Thinks France has been the support and bulwark of all the republics -- Holland, Switzerland and America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. de Neufville's opinion of the proposals made him; question of accepting bills for large amounts drawn on Mr. Laurens. The States General have unanimously guaranteed the five millions; will now demand an answer to his former memorial regarding a triple or quadruple alliance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's mind too extensive to be entirely absorbed in public affairs; dares to hope that the woes of his Amelia will be listened to; her husband dead; left with four small children and expecting a fifth; nothing to support them; begs that the proceeds from the sale of the map and pamphlets be sent her; has written in vain to Governor Pownall and Mr. [John] Almon.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An American sailor imprisoned in France; begs for speedy release.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the vessels disappointed to Commodore Gillon's convoy; no shadow of blame can be laid against them in the matter, and if Franklin had refused to pay the bills it would have been a violation of all public faith; Mr. Gillon's breach of faith after borrowing large sums from them, and his false representations; the Directors and Captains of the ships are the people who should be questioned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolution adopted in favor of the loan of five million florins. Instructions from Congress received by Mr. Adams, enjoining him to insist upon a reply from Holland to their proposals made the previous spring. His confidential relations with the Pensionaries of three Dutch towns and other distinguished persons.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote to her husband eight months ago but has received no answer; desires to know if any letter for her has come to Franklin's hands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intends to call with the deputy of the Company at Metz who furnished Mr. Robert Morris with clothing for the United States; encloses the Company's new memorial (4p.); hopes Franklin will obtain from the Ministry more favorable conditions.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a translation of Mr. Van Arp's letter showing that the ship's Directors are the only persons answerable for the goods loaded on board the Dutch vessels; will do anything in their power to show their disinterestedness and sincerity but no blame attaches to them nor is there any reason why Franklin should refuse the payment of their bills.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires Franklin's direction concerning the bills drawn upon Mr. Laurens; improbable that any other bills will be drawn upon himself or anyone else in that department. Thinks that de Neufville and Son's bills should be paid at the expiration of their time, as otherwise it will be fatal to their house and a bolt upon American affairs; de Neufville is not the ruling power in the concern, but has done all he can and is not responsible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Languishing for a word in reply to his last five letters; a volume of opuscula on various philosophical subjects kept back for Franklin's sanction; on receipt of Franklin's answer, will send the whole collection to M. Le Bègue de Presle to be printed. Account of two curious experiments, one the production of a certain kind of clear smoke, the other a manner of setting fire to a metal wire. His ignorance of the business enterprise be engaged in with Mr. Wharton; Dr. Bancroft and Mr. Coffyn. Trusts the Peace Conference has been sucessful; hopes his countrymen will take revenge upon the barbarous English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers congratulations on the capture of Cornwallis and the flattering situation of affairs in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin to forward him the promised letters of recommendation, as he is about to start on his journey.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fearing Franklin may not know how to direct an answer to her letter of the day before, sends her address.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Burning with a desire to live in the United States; dedicates to Franklin the small poem adjoined.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Much insulted at the treatment he has received from Mr. Hector and the Major de Place of Brest; has been twice arrested and is at present a prisoner writing with sergeant at his back; begs that the Marquis de Castries be asked to write to this Hector, who is in possession of his commission, passport, letters of credit and of recommendation, with Mr. W.T. Franklin's last letter ordering him to Brest.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asked Messrs. Van Arp and Co., Directors of the "Aurora" and "Liberty" to make some demand for the pretended damages; in reply they demanded 60,000 francs; Mr.[John] Adams's opinion; they approve of Franklin's resolution to have the matter settled by arbitration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Perceives that M. Gérard's absence has prevented any knowledge being obtained relative to his affair with Comte d'Arbaud. Has discovered a mistake of the Notary Public at Guadeloupe, concerning the name of the commanding officer who so rudely interfered in the affair of the prize, "Terrible"; gives the authentic names of the commanders of the frigates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing Mr. Williams's letter; begs that Mr. Clement be spoken to in regard to it and tbat his answer be transmitted as soon as possible as the affair is pressing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is angry with him, he captures a whole army in America, burgoynes Cornwallis, takes cannons and vessels, munitions, men, etc., and the Gazette alone announces the news to his friends, whilst he gives no sign of life. He must feel twenty years younger because of this good news which should bring a lasting peace after glorious war. Shall remain angry with him until she hears from him; in the meantime shall compose a triumphal march for him and shall send it to him, write him, and even love him with all her heart.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Proe. of Am. Philos. Soc., XL, 107 and also in Putnam's Monthly, Oct., 1906, 39.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that he will write at the bottom of the enclosed summary everything he knows about Major Franks, and what he thinks that officer has done with the carriage so obligingly lent him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to settle in Philadelphia, the further home of arts and government; asks for advice and letters of recommendation. Through Mr. Carmichael, has heard the news of the capture of Cornwallis and his army; hopes it will hasten the procedings of the dilatory Spanish Court; this victory together with the latter one of General [Nathanael] Greene against the Charlestown garrison, has entirely freed the Southern Colonies from their long sufferings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending two little works in verse which were published at Nantes during the celebration there of the birth of the Dauphin. Requests Franklin to present them to Mme. la Marquise de la Fayette.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his promises to dine with them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the sister of M. de la Villeboisnet; begs his influence for her son who wants to be a midshipman.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to dine with Franklin at Madame des Deux-Ponts's; offers him seats in his box at the "Comédie FranÇaise" for the same day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters received from Mr. Dana, who has been politely treated by the Marquis de Vérac; when he wrote, had not yet communicated his mission to the Russian Ministry; his opinion of Dutch policy not raised by his journey to the North; great respects for the Dutch Minister at Petersburg; speaks prudently of the Prince de Potemkin, the Comte de Panin and the Comte d'Ostermann. Considers the last speech of the King of England rather inflammatory; his admiration for the art and address with which England manages Holland and some of the Northern powers; Lord Stormont's acceptance of Russia's mediation between England and Holland, a masterpiece of its matchless effrontery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning le Sieur Vernié who entered the service of the United States in 1777 and has lately been reported killed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was gunner on the Continental ship, "Confederacy" when she was captured; his present cruel confinement; begs Franklin to procure his exchange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assistance he has rendered Americans escaped from English prisons. Desires the position of Consul-General for the United States in Basse Normandie; sure that M. St. John de Crevecoeur would endorse this appointment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her son a lieutenant in the regiment of Anhault; desires to serve in the American Army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his appointment as Deputy-Consul of his district which Mr. Barclay is willing to authorize; reasons why he would like it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His fortune not adequate to support a family of five children; if the United States will provide him with a comfortable position, will devote himself to their service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of Franklin's perfect benevolence not one whit exaggerated; has experienced it himself; expresses the most enthusiastic gratitude.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Mr. Jay, which advises his return to Spain, and his departure from that country to America; desires Franklin's opinion; is persuaded Mr. Jay has something of consequence to send to the Congress and wishes a trustworthy messenger. Complains of his treatment by the commandant; believes M. and Madame Deseitre, persons of infamous character, are at the bottom of it; the lady has imposed upon Mr. Hancock of Boston and consequently on several respectable people in Brest.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: L'Accademia di Scienze, Lettre, ed Arti, di Padova. Padus

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certificate of membership.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a second letter for General de Steuben, which he begs Franklin to guard until the Baron's arrival in Paris, if the report he true that he arrives in January.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the form of passport granted by Franklin and desiring him to make any alterations which he may judge proper in virtue of recent changes; inclination shown by their merchants to unite in commercial interest with the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His return after being captured in the brig "Franklin"; has not taken command of the brig "Antonia"; this vessel being American property, begs for a commission and letter of marque.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging their exchange; in all about sixty or seventy prisoners, who were captured in the West Indies, and sent to England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting that he and his lieutenant be set at liberty, or at least informed of the nature of their crime.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has acquinted Mr. [Samuel?] Vaughan with directions concerning Mr. [Henry] Laurens's support. Succeeded in removing Mr. Gouverneur to better quarters. Need of a further remittance by the beginning of January; nearly eight hundred prisoners in all; question of procuring a speedy exchange. Comparison of the circumstances of Lord Cornwallis and Gen. Burgoyne; the Ministers' predilection for the former.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Did not receive Franklin's favor of the 10th inst. until too late to wait upon him. Encloses Mr. Bridgen's letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Project on a work on legislation.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 114).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a memoir concerning an affair of consequence to every French corsair.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Denies that the lack of consideration shown him was due to any indiscretion on his part; before this time, has always been treated by the French with the greatest politness.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know whether he can rely upon facts stated in the "Brief Account of the American-English Revolution from 1774 to 1778" by an American ; needs only Franklin's endorsement to continue the work he has projected; mentions the principal statements the veracity of which he desires to ascertain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the first part of his memoirs, and the journal of his voyage to Kamchatka; promises to forward the rest of his memoirs and his journal of Madagascar.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The owners of the two vessels, who have the clothing belonging to the United States, have agreed to deliver it upon the conditions enumerated.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Terms and conditions made with the owners of the ships who have agreed to deliver the goods to Mr. Adams; they will pay the owners and Franklin can reimburse them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enjoys Franklin's pleasantries in what he calls his bad French. Thinks much better of his French than he does himself. Wants him to write often.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, October, 1906, 41.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: According to orders received from Mr. Bondfield, sent Franklin a turkey stuffed with truffles.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Henry Wild, a prudent man who has a scheme to lay before Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his promise to send him an introductory line to the Marquis de Castries.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Confirming their former statement that the Continental goods are now at the disposal of the Hon. Tho[ma]s Barclay and His Excellency, Mr. Adams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pays his respects to Franklin. Has been with his eldest boy in Switzerland; his wife an invalid; is visiting Mr. [Robert] Pigott.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for leave of absence for Jean Pierre Le Duc at present in the service of South Carolina, who received two wounds as mentioned in the enclosed certificates.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. William Cheever, of Boston, who expects to spend some time in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apology for not informing Franklin earlier of the loss of the "Alexander," a prize made by the "Indian" now called "South Carolina"; owing to his wounds and lack of money, was obliged to rest some time at Dunkirk. Hopes to wait on Franklin shortly and ask his kindness on behalf of certain American Prisoners, whose names he mentions as having fought with singular courage.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies to the Untited States Congress and to Dr. Franklin to be appointed Consul for the United States at Havre.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's kindness to his brother-in-law and to himself.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging his influence on behalf of Captain Conyngham's crew who, since 1777, have awaited not only their wages but part of their prizemoney.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of money paid to Col. William Richardson and sundry prisoners arrived from England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the enclosed from Capt. John Angus and endorsing his request for a commission.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Chaumont, Marie-Thérèse Jougues Le Ray de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishing him a happy New Year and many of them; congratulates him on the surrender of Cornwallis. Her affection and admiration for Franklin and her friendship for his grandson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him all good wishes and acknowledging his past kindness with gratitude.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. J. has called to see him; said he was disappointed at not hearing from Franklin, as he expected both advice and financial help from him. Mr. J. seems to be in need of money, he still owes the writer 30,000 piastres.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A serio-comic address to Dr. Franklin from Nice by the Brillon family and few mutual friends on the occasion of the New Year.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, December, 1906, 316.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returns papers taken by mistake from Dr. Franklin's office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly of the Continental brig "Lexington"; petitions for wages and prize money due him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from M. Peuch, proprietor of the Utrecht Gazette, and offering to forward Franklin's reply.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a letter which he has just received from M. Didelot "Fermier-Général" recommending M. Gellée who was about to depart for America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting letters of introduction for M. Dillion des Gayères who was leaving for America to take charge of food supplies for the troops.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot take breakfast with him. Is still weak and much affected by the disaster which has happened to the Bouffé house. The ladies of that house were her friends.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been very seriously ill. Will not be able to go to see Franklin for a long time.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Premises to dine with Franklin. Thanks him and his son for their kind attention when she was ill.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites Franklin to spend a few days with her and her mother at their country place.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Believes in being punctual and faithful with friends even in small matters. Is leading a quiet, uniform life in the country.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Last letter she will write to Franklin from this place. Returns to Passy next Monday. Is often dissatisfied with her own letters; do not fully express her sentiments. Will continue, however, to write them to Franklin who should soon have a volume of them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will return to Passy on the 21st. Hopes to see Franklin every Wednesday and Saturday evening at tea with her usual guests, Le Veillard, Abbé de la Roche and Abbé Morellet, Mme. Grand and her niece, M. Grand and M. Pagin.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Proc. Am. Philos. soc, XI, 105 and in Putnam's Monthly, Oct., 1906, 38.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been very ill with a nervous trouble. Did not receive visitors, but sorry they did not make an exception in his case. Asks him to call to see her as soon as possible.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of Franklin's forgetfulness of her. Has learned that he was at the opera on the day the building was burned down. How uncertain is life and by what a slender thread it hangs. Without the sweets of friendship, life would not be worth living.
(In French)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, Nov., 1906, 170.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been ill for 69 days. Asks Franklin to write to her if he cannot call to see her. Hopes Franklin will find her letters easier to read than formerly, as she now writes in a larger hand on his son's advice. If she were a journalist Franklin's works in French would soon be published. Is afraid her husband may steal some of the droll stories which she is collecting for Franklin's amusement and tell them himself.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Referring to a day spent by Franklin with them at the above place. Does not like the idea of making a long journey the coming winter for the benefit of her health.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin the music he has asked for. The idea of his approaching departure from France seems like a painful dream to her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Feels it almost as hard to go to Paris and leave Franklin as to go to Nice. Will go to see him sometimes and hopes he will be able to come to see her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applying for the position of Secretary to Dr. Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning the "Gazette of Amsterdam" and request him to send them the letter of recommendation for M. Louis Jolly.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to write at once to the Count de Vergennes, requesting an escort for the vessel, the "Marquis de la Fayette."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of "interventions" in [Jonathan] Williams [Jr.]'s drafts.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Claim for freight due to his vessel the "Marquis de la Fayette" chartered by Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advises Franklin to postpone his ball to another time because of the bad news about the French and Spanish fleets.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to notify Mr. Andrew Patton to go on board a vessel at Rouen bound for Cadiz and to give him a commission from Congress to engage in privateering against the English.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Franklin to the ball to be given in her honor by M. and Mme. la Maréchale de Richelien.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if Dr. Franklin has remitted to Favier the price of the 11 volumes of the History of China.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a packet for America.
(In French)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin copy of a letter which was written by a great King's Minister.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for restoring her to life and hope. Is not yet strong enough to go to see him. Will be the first trip she will take.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his letter and news contained therein. Hopes to see him at dinner on Wednesday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to loan her his carriage for a day as her own is broken.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him for news about Chevalier de Chastellux, her intimate friend, who was reported in the "Courier de l'Europe" to have been killed in an engagement.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to have a few minutes' conversation with him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is again anxious and uneasy after hearing about a battle between Rochambeau's troops and those under General Clinton. Asks for a true account of the affair.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking him to loan her a French-English dictionary.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Baron de Blome has just called at her house and told her the good news brought by Mr. [John] Laurens about the surrender of CornWallis. Asks Franklin to lend her, for a few minutes, the map showing how Cornwallis was surrounded.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to see Franklin on Sunday. Will, however, call before then and let him know the contents of letters reveived by her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
