scopecontent.p: Thanks him for sending her news about her friend. Would like to see Franklin soon and dine with him. Would have written to him in English but is not yet sufficiently proficient. Mme. De Tonnerre is in a serious condition, her life is despaired of. Returns the German papers. Will send tickets for theatre soon to Franklin's grandson.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to lend her the collection of romances by J. J. Rousseau and offers to procure for him a copy of Abbé Raynal's work.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about Franklin's health. Will go to see him as soon as she recovers from a severe cold. Saw a few days ago a relative of J.J. Rousseau's who came from Bassors. Is a noted traveler and linguist. Describes his extraordinary costume. Recalls her singing of "Diēu d'amour" for Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending two certificates to prevent the payment of certain bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: concerning the Holland loan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. de La Flotte who is going to America as adjutant to Count de Wickenstein. M. de La Flotte's father holds an important position in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and has rendered many services to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advises transferring M. Boux, who does nothing at Nantes although in the States' service, to Amsterdam where he would be more useful in forwarding the construction of the "Indian." On their apprehension of fire being set to this ship, he has written to have four men put on board to watch her night and day; if this precaution is not sufficent, advises getting her insured against fire which would cost about two thousand florins. Prudence seems to require this sacrifice. Asks his approbation on this head.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her own grief, and that of all their Society, at Franklin's inability to be with them the following day; begs him to name his own time for coming to Sanois and planting a tree in her garden.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking him to fix a day to spend at her country place before her departure.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will not have any music or be able to receive Franklin to-day on account of the illness of her brother. Will call for Franklin as soon as possible thereafter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: If Franklin approves of the enclosed letter to Gen. [Henry] Knox, it will be sent by the next post.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was employed as a cook by Franklin, presents a claim for a sum of money due to her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will have to devote the afternoon to preparing the memorial for to-morrow. Requests Franklin to make his excuses to M. Chalut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a book and an unsigned letter from R[alph] lzard. Begs Franklin to appoint an hour when he may receive his commands for America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin the estimate of the Board of War with the prices. Cannot dine with him Sunday, that being the day the Count de Vergennes has appointed for his taking leave.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Dr. Franklin to dine with him on Tuesday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A young Irishman taken prisoner by the Brest fleet on his way to Jamaica; begs Franklin to procure his liberty and passage to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a map of the two Carolinas and Georgia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to see Franklin Sunday and make up for past neglect. Congratulating him on his seventy-five years. Messages for M. Ingen Housz.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received the Gazette sent by Franklin. Had invited him to the "Te Deum" celebration for the birth of the Dauphin. Learns since that it is to be at an earlier hour and preceded by a Mass. Thinks Franklin will not care to attend the ceremony. Asks if Franklin can give him another copy of Mesmer's book.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites him to M. D'arcy's house to try M. Belton's gun.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intoducing M. Frenel who wishes to know the present value of some paper money issued by Congress. Inquires if he knows a Mr. Iry, of Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring of Franklin about the reported success of Gen. [Nathanael] Greene in North Carolina.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Count and Countess de Maillebois are to dine with her and she has promised that Franklin will come also. Requests him and his grandson to accept her invitation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A resident of Charlestown, S.C., who came to France with Capt. Cochran; offers his services to Dr. Franklin as Secretary; is well versed in French as he was for eight years in the College of the Four Narions at Paris. Captain Cochran and himself married two sisters in South Carolina. Came over to serve the province in doing the affairs of the vessel, and explaining to the French merchants the needs of their trade and the manufacturing the different goods proper for their country, and has fulfilled his mission. Speaks and writes the French language fluently. Mr.Deane is conversant with his abilities. Would sacrifice his many enjoyments in life to be attched to so illustrious a gentleman engaged in so noble a cause, and whom the whole world admires.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Queen gave birth to a Prince yesterday evening, to whom the King has given the title of Duke of Normandy. Reception to-morrow at Versailles.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his attentions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Three months since he has had the pleasure of seeing Frankin or the Lady of Auteuil [Mme. Helvétius]; would like to be with them all the time.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regretting that Mme. Helvétius cannot be at home to receive the Misses Alexander; her suggestion for a meeting at Franklin's house.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, I, 86.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranging that his sister, niece and M. Marmontel may visit Franklin Sunday morning before dinner with Mme. Helvétius.
(In French.)

bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, I, 86.

(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presumes that Franklin is ill, perhaps intentionally, as he is not to be seen now when all Paris wishes to acclaim him. Sends some verses suggested to him by the circumstance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was absent on business when Franklin called to see him. Asks Franklin to let him know what day he can come and take dinner with him and family.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a notice about an allegorical engraving, the original drawing of which he presented to the Queen.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a convict at Brest; petitions Franklin to obtain his release and offers to serve as a cannoneer in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers a portfolio, the work of his hands, and asks him to obtain his release from prison to go to America to work in its service.
(In triplicate. In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the letter which Franklin promised to forward to America with his despatches.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A debt due him from Congress; his affairs in Mr. Bingham's hands; begs Franklin's aid in sending his memoir to Congress and writing a letter on his behalf.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presenting his poem on the birth of the Dauphin; therein will be found the heroes of Boston, especially the famous Washington.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a convict at Brest; petitions Franklin to obtain his release.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests Franklin to obtain his release from prison to enter the American service.
(In triplicate. In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting payment of their account for freight and other charges paid by them on a shipment of clothing, uniforms etc., made by them to Bordeaux, for account of Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has called to see him about an historical work he is writing and in which he wishes to give particulars about Franklin.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to go Boston to work at his trade as gunsmith and furbisher. Begs to be given a free passage.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has already read the work and gave it to M. [Ferdinand] Grand for Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing that the two young Americans can perfectly well live in Boulogne if they are not in the service of the English; no passport needed for Madame Newenham to enter France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending cards of invitation for a meeting of the Royal Society of Medicine; will read the eulogy on the famous Dr.Fothergill.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notifying Franklin not to pay any drafts purposing to be endorsed by him unless his signature is followed by the mark X.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires a letter of introduction from Franklin to Gov. [John] Hancock, of Massachusetts, for Messrs, Galatheau and Compère who are going with the ship "Marquis de la Fayette" to Boston to bring legal proceedings against a Captain Purien and a certain Marc Lafitte for misusing and embezzling funds entrusted to their care by a merchant of Bordeaux.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to Louis Joli, a merchane of Paris, who has settled at Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the establishment of commercial relations between Flanders and the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for seeds of different plants and flowers grown in North America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describing the condition of the Vicomtesse de Clermont de Tonnere who is dangerously ill.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ship "Congress," Capt. [George] Geddes, and brig "[Don] Galvez," Capt. [Silas] Jones, from Havana, brought in a brig bound from the coast of Africa to London, seized as a prize. Will soon trouble him with the condemnation proceedings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has delivered the letter and parcel to Mr. Alexander and sent bundle of books to M. Le Bègue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gratitude for Franklin's kindness and good advice; messages to the Brillon family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A short disquisition on love of self and love of truth.
(In French.)

origination.persname: La Blancherie, Claude-Mammès de Pahin Champlain de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting his presence at an exhibition of works of art, to be held on the 4th.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a clergyman who desires to go to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New Year's good wishes; understands Mr. [Thomas] Barclay will first speak to him on the question of the Consulship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the escape of nine American prisoners from Deal, and their final arrival at Dunkirk; has supplied them with money to defray their expenses to Paris; amounts due him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a confidential audience for several wealthy manufacturers who wish to transport their business to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented from paying his respects to Franklin by serious illness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning two more bills of exchange drawn on Mr. Laurens. Good wishes for the New Year. Reason why the mediation of Russia will not be accepted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding him of his promise to give orders for the release of Capt. [John] Kinnier, in exchange for Capt. [Thomas] Bell; presumes Mr. Schweighauser's death has interrupted the affair; begs that it may be carried through as soon as possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin as a brother Mason to aid him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the Bipontine Edition of the Classics; begs Franklin to become a subscriber.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 126).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the supplies left by Mr. Gillon; hopes Franklin will approve of his proceedings; exonerates M. de Neufville from all blame.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has invented a powerful liquid which extinguishes fire even when produced by the most inflammable materials; offers to prove this statement.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the difficulty he has experienced in finding a particular kind of paper desired by Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the estate of Sophie Mengeh, née Mittler. One Theo. Mieger, a tailor in Philadelphia, is entitled to a part of the estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes Franklin has received her brother's work; it has received little or no encouragement in England. Begs his assistance, as she is at present very much distressed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding two letters from two of Franklin's friends in England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a French officer, named Vernié, killed in the service of the United States; desires certificate of his death with any details known to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Would like to live always at Nice solely on account of its healthy climate and the beauties of nature to be found there. Likens it to the Garden of Eden or the Elysian Fields.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has six letters for Mr. Bondfield; begs for his address.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the request of the Secretary of War, recommends Capt. de Segond to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipted bill for three copying machines.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to become a citizen of the United States; is about to adopt five children whom he will dedicate to the service; desires his expenses paid.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Satisfaction at the particularity with which their bills were accepted; feared more for the credit of the United States than for the injury to themselves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Endorsing the request of Captain Angus for a commission; Franklin's refusal would cause great suffering to several important merchants in Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Endorsing the request for a commission and letter of marque for John Angus of the brig "Antonia"; the nature of the armament and the character of Capt. Angus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to grant a commission for the brig "Antonia," commanded by Capt. John Angus; this vessel destined for America, laden with a rich cargo; offers to give any guarantees Franklin may desire.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The brig "Antonia" loaded and ready to sail; detained only for want of a commission from Franklin; begs that it may be sent him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the enclosed, just received from Mr. Bridgen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their miserable confinement; all their little money and clothes go to help those still more destitute; number of men driven by misery to accept service with the English; America charged with treating her citizens like criminals; entreat Franklin to procure their exchange.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ready to depart; determined to merit Franklin's good opinion.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter to be forwarded to his brother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a young Dane who was recommended to Franklin in 1777 and sailed for America; served Congress and worked for Mr. Lee; his capture on the "Alliance," and escape from England; having no letters or passports, was arrested by Mr. Ollivier who promised him a passage to America; since then has heard nothing; begs for aid.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a Passport for his brig "Yorktown." Hopes the turkey stuffed with truffles proved an acceptable Christmas dish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [Henry] Laurens enlarged but not discharged; his ill health with other circumstances determined this step; his departure for Bath. Encloses a statement of account with the prisoners; sorry to have to demand more cash; has not yet been able to procure a reply to his memorial relative to their exchange; thinks if Franklin wrote to the Secretary of State it would bring the matter to an issue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was informed by Mr. Nesbitt of his possible exchange for Capt. Thomas Bell; is very anxious to obtain his liberty and a passport to Ostend, where he may get a passage home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for his efforts to serve her father; at present rejoicing in the news of his liberty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for tidings of his son, le Chevalier de Bretigney, an officer in the American army, from whom he has not received a line for over two years; his son's service and adventures since his departure in June, 1777.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin of his safe arrival with the "Alliance"; the Marquis de la Fayette, Vicomte de Noailles and General Duportail among his passengers; his orders are to proceed at once on a cruize till the first of March, when he returns to receive Franklin's despatches; if the French sailors are removed from his crew, it will be out of his power to go to sea.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning certain money matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing him of the arrival of the brig "Betsey."

origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking permission to see Franklin the following day at twelve.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transmitting an extract of his account.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delights at America's successes.
(In French.)
A.E. By Dr. Franklin. Is sensibly touched by his kind expressions. It is the work of God and the King of France. (In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a contract which he wishes drawn up with a certain person in America, to supply him with various articles of merchandise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kindness of Mr. and Mrs. Bache; happy in finding that her scheme cannot fail of success; describes Franklin's four grandchildren.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know if certain persons belonging to the "Alliance" at the time when she helped in the capture of the "Serapis" and "Countess of Scarborough" will receive any of the prize-money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A second letter from Mr. Jay has determined him to set out for Madrid; offering to carry any despatches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his safe arrival after a passage of twenty days. Congratulating him on the good news of peace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Dubois, who has something of interest to communicate to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Before accepting certain orders from a Philadelphia firm established at l'Orient, desires to know their reputation and standing.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his work in medicine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statement of accounts.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending for a position in the American army, an officer who quitted the service of the Margrave d'Anspach when that Prince supplied England with troops.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to become a citizen of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His letter of the 28th inst.; aware of Franklin's attitude towards such requests; hoped this particular case might be treated as an exception; desires an answer that he may show to his friend.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Difficulty experienced in procuring his full complement of sailors. Expressing his willingness to take over certain public goods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a bill of exchange.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Directed a friend at Lyons to send him certain samples of paper. Desires the enclosed letter forwarded to his uncle, head of the Monastery of St. Sulpice at Montreal.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his note; communicated it to the merchants of Nantes who will wait on Franklin shortly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Detailed explanation of the use of passports or registers; Franklin mistaken in supposing such applications are made to cover irregular or illicit commerce; encloses copies [2 p.] of the permission granted by the Ministry, according to the forms established in such cases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has given a note of introduction to a Mr. Delon who came to Nice with Lord Cholmondeley as his companion or preceptor. Probably desires to bring about a meeting between Lord Cholmondeley and Franklin. Particulars about the young Lord and his Mentor. Surmises as to their real object in wishing to meet Franklin. Her health continues to improve. Her Husband being no longer under the evil influence of a certain person shows her every kindness and attention.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remarks about the soul.
(In French.)

origination.persname: Conti, Louis-François-Joseph de Bourbon, comte de la Marche and prince de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a passport for his grooms who go to England to purchase dogs.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a passport for the brig "Ernelia" at Morlaix, commanded by John H. Richard and bound for America; desiring also a permit to ship American sailors wherever found; some sailors taken from them by a Lieut. Gill of the "Alliance"; protests vehemently against such conduct.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the acceptance of certain bills in which both he and Mr. Bache are concerned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Capt. John Foster Williams, lately arrived from prison; hopes in consequence of his letter, fifty-three of their poor countrymen may be liberated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's promise to return him his bill of exchange.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the Continental goods left by Mr. Gillon at Amsterdam; contention between Messrs. de Neufville and Van Arp as to the possession of a part of these goods; money needed to send them to America; desires to have a particular sum passed to his account.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for procuring the exchange of Capt. [Thomas] Bell for Capt. [John] Kinnier. Desires information about certain bills drawn by Mr. W[illia]m Trent of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bills drawn on Mr. [Henry] Laurens, which, if Franklin cannot meet, must protested. His reasons for thinking there will be neither peace nor mediation; probability of the States making a treaty with France and America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will wait upon Franklin that afternoon, respecting the letter he spoke of.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring him to dine with them. Sends a memoir (64a, see infra) which he could not well refuse to present to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his services to the United States from 1775-1778, when he was captured by the English; his arrival in France; destitute of everything; desires to obtain the salary due him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes for news of his nephew, who went to Philadelphia at the commencement of the war and entered business with a commercial house there; rumor of his having been assassinated; begs Franklin to ascertain the truth of these reports, and if the young man is dead, to get some friend to look after his effects.
(In French.)
A. E. by Dr. Franklin. Will write to America and make the inquiries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The merchants of Nantes will wait on Franklin on Thursday. Efforts made by his protectors at Court to obtain for him the position of Consul at Charlestown; begs Franklin, when he goes to Court, to use his influence on his behalf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the sum due him by Congress for his services as Secretary to Mr. Henry Laurens; acknowledgment of a part payment by Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to meet the expenses of a town-house; his wife and daughter have gone to the country while he has taken rooms in town; any omissions in his correspondence due to worry over this enforced separation from his family. Affairs in Holland; resolution taken by the town of Dort relative to a mediation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a circular (1 p.) of his new business connections. Account of the service rendered the United States by the brave Capt. Macatter, who commanded the "Black Princess"; his capture by the English; all efforts to obtain his release have proved useless; the English insist in regarding him as a traitor; begs Franklin's assistance in obtaining his freedom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken prisoner six months before, but made his escape; possessed a few American bills which he forwarded to Franklin for acceptance; Franklin's refusal to decide the matter for twelve days has put him to great inconvenience.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will wait on Franklin in a fortnight with the samples of paper. Sent him yesterday two works by a physician [Gastellier] of Gâtinais, as a slight mark of his respect and veneration; his wish to become a member of the Scientific Society of Philadelphia [American Philosophical Society].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Entreats his kindness on behalf of three English officers, taken prisoner with Lord Cornwallis; their names are Messrs. Harry Calvert, George and Thomas Scott; if wounded or sick, begs to be allowed to assist and help them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Grubb, who intends to settle in France and go into business with Mr. Hazlehurst.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Information concerning the shipping of certain goods from Brest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No American vessels at l'Orient and none immediately expected; the "Alliance" sailed on Saturday in company with Capt. Angus.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Question of transporting the stores to America. In favor of the "Alliance" being allowed the indulgence of a cruise; promise from the Marquis de Castries to let Barry have all the American sailors he can get in any French ports.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II, 15.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The company duly appreciative of Franklin's kindness; their determination is firm to emigrate directly; certain privileges which they desire from Congress; wish to know of some trustworthy Captain. Asking if engines used in cutting small screws have been introduced into America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written to his brother, General von Steuben, twice, but received no answer. Requests Franklin to forward enclosed letter. His first letter, dated Dec. 19th, 1780, was in care of Major von Glöden. His second letter was dated Aug. 15th, 1781, in care of Dr. Franklin. Is worried, because he has heard neither from his brother nor from Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Again requesting that his bills of exchange may either be accepted or protested and returned to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring Franklin's presence at the "Collège Royal" where he expects to lecture.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has not been able to procure proper conveyances for the Continental supplies; every part of the business has been involved in difficulty, vexation and expense; will come to Paris, if Franklin deems a consultation necessary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses letter for his son in the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolution in favor of mediation passed in the States-General.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Larwood and Van Hassett and Van Suchtelen. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certain bills of exchange drawn on Mr. [Henry] Laurens, but through his unfortunate detention in England, not accepted; begs Franklin's influence for their acceptance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Again requesting a passport for their brig at Morlaix.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have drawn on Franklin for the sum due them for disbursements to twenty-six American seamen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her unprotected state without father or mother; both her brothers absent; begs Franklin to forward her letters to her brother in Philadelphia and to send any answers to her.
(In French.)
A. E. by Dr. Franklin. Promising to do what she asks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their good friend [the Dowager Duchess of Deux-Ponts] desires Franklin and his grandson to dine with her any day the following week. News received from Cadiz of a victory won by Gen. [Nathanael] Greene over the English at sixty miles from Charleston. The fleet has set sail from Brest.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for the wages and prize-money due him during his service on board the "Lexington"; his subsequent sufferings in prison; his destitute condition.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin the three periodicals he desired.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of a large collection of uniforms, etc., intended for the American army, captured on board a French vessel, and now in London; offers to sell them to Franklin for the United States.
(In French.)
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. His orders completed; cannot at present treat for the clothes; believes if the owners would send them to America, they might sell them to advantage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their good friend [la Douairière. Duchesse de Deux-Ponts] will be delighted to see Franklin on the 23d.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends two of his "résumé mémoirs"; expects his business to come before Council and be judged to his satisfaction on Monday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires the position of Consul at the above port.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is desirous of waiting upon Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking the name of some work, which treats of the war in America, for Comte de Ségur; begs Franklin to procure him certain maps from London.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to subscribe to "Spectacle de la Galerie de Dusseldorf."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of money due for his expenditures on behalf of prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Disgrace to the National credit from the non-payment of the bills; hopes France will once more step to their relief. Question of his own salary. The conquest of Minorca and the intended siege of Gibraltar much discussed at present; the Spaniards reproach the French troops with indifference and cowardice; a different opinion of French gallantry in America; his admiration and love for la Fayette; only exceeded by his feeling for Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of nearly two hundred prisoners in wretched confinement; many would have perished during the winter but for a small subscription raised by a few individuals; begs Franklin to use his influence to have an exchange effected.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Bright, Michael, Champion Wood, Levy Yonger and Bartholemus Cashman. Havre-de-Grace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of their escape from Forton Prison, and their arrival in France, only to be placed under arrest; desire their liberty and enough money to take them to l'Orient; complain bitterly of such unjust treatment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a prospectus for a Military Academy which he is starting.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. Will be glad to see him when he calls.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning Captain Folger's bond and oath.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers his services to Congress to paint a series of pictures, celebrating the American feats of arms; his portrait of Washington; some of his work at the Palais Bourbon and L'école Royale.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In compliance with Franklin's directions, had an interview with the Comte de Vergennes; the sum will be immediately communicated to Franklin; wishes its augmentation could be obtained; the petition to the Marquis de Castries will be presented at once and the answer sent to Passy as soon as possible; this peculiar situation calls him to Versailles two or three times a week.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the vessel purchased by him to convey the goods to America; bills drawn on Franklin; amount owing him by Congress. Letter received from Mr. Moylan with an account of disbursements for the "Alliance."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of M. de Montigny, wounded on board the American frigate "South Carolina"; his destitution; desires the pay due him as well as his share of the prize-money; encloses certificate (1 p.) to prove his claim.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Protest against their treatment (see XXIV, 97); their earnest wish to get home as soon as possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Protesting against being sent on board a man-of-war; desires Franklin to let his parents and his brother William know that he is well, and that Champion Wood made his escape with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received no answer to the memoir he addressed to Franklin; hopes he will accede to his request and desires his certificate returned.
(In French.)
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. "Not being able to do anything in such affairs I return his certificate."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him the required instructions (2 p. in French) in order to reimburse Mr. [John] Adams for the sum lent Mr. [Francis M.] Dana.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His safe arrival with the frigate "Alliance"; can only wait the return of the post for Franklin's despatches. Very poor success on his last cruise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's letters handed him by Messrs. Hazlehurst and Grubb, to whom he has rendered every little service in his power; various manufactories they have visited. Messages from his wife and Mr. Ridley. The date of Marquis de la Fayette's return.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him papers relating to considerable affairs in America in which his friend, la Marquise de Cassiny is interested; desires their return at his earliest convenience so that he may carry them to the Marquis de la Fayette. Has been confined to his house for five weeks with the gout.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hears that Franklin is considering the purchase of a vessel; describes one which he thinks will suit him.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if Mr. Franklin will be in; wishes to see him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him to forward a letter to Lieut.-Col. Brewse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Situation of the goods sold by Mr. Gillon; conditions upon which he will be able to procure them and forward them to America. Expects the "General Sullivan" in ten days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the death of their father.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his dispute with the French sailors who came with the "Alliance" from Boston; difficulty of procuring American sailors; habit of the French to trump up an account against any American who is desired to go on board; given an instance of this nefarious practice; out of his power to go to Brest; if the goods were at L'Orient, might take a certain number. Advises against sending any more powder and arms to the Eastern provinces; his reasons. Is stretching his orders further than he likes in order to wait for Franklin's despatches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transmitting a copy of Cicero's Cato; Mr. Strahan afraid it is not the desired edition; Mr. S[trahan] would have written, but he has not yet recovered from his defeat that morning in the House of Commons; thinks the proceedings open a prospect of peace. His intention of coming to Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him tickets for a meeting of the Royal Society of Medicine and begging the honor of his presence on that occasion.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing him that the Spaniards are in possession of Fort St. Philippe [Port Mahon, Minorca].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his kind advice and offers of service; has written the Minister to request that their part of the prize-money may be paid to their attorney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His funds more than exhausted; Mr. [Edmund] Burke's intention of bringing in a bill for a general exchange of prisoners; some hope of success after what passed the night before. Mr. [Henry] L[aurens] considers himself restricted from writing to persons abroad, but will do all the good in his power.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a letter of recommendation to the Comte d'Aranda, whose protection he desires in order to join "la Pobordia" on the island of Minorca.
(In Spanish.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left London the day before; the King's-answer to the various addresses; has letters for Franklin which will disclose the sentiments of parties in England. Had the good fortune to procure the liberty of Gouverneur and Carson after Mr. Hodgson had tried in vain. Expects to be at St. Germain by Wednesday.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing Mr. Guichen's arrival at Cadiz with the fleet. Necessity of the French Court advancing a sufficient sum of money to enable Mr. Jay to discharge the bills already accepted; has been haunted by this business for weeks past. Account of their negotiations; the instructions of M. Del Campo not yet ready. Coldness towards him of the Marquis d'Aranda; reasons for this change of manner. Elation in Spain caused by the taking of Fort St. Philippe; the siege of Gibraltar determined upon. General esteem acquired by Mr. Page, a young American volunteer who acted as the Duc de Brillon's Aide-de-camp at Minorca.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Alliance" not fit to take dry goods on board; in a gale of wind; impossible to keep them from being damaged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Determination on the part of his father and two other gentlemen to purchase lands in America; asks certain important questions on the subject. The enclosed letter from John will explain why he delayed his departure. After the late votes in the House of Commons, is in hopes of seeing Franklin soon. The instant his father can proceed without confiscation of his property, he will embark for America with all his family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has purchased a brigantine which he wishes to despatch immediately for Boston; desires a passport as she is American property. Messages from Franklin's friends in Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Lefevre of Lisbon, who desires an interview on particular business.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the enclosed letter; as an officer of the United States, cannot suffer the subjects of America to be treated in the manner they are; the author of the letter is the son of Mr. Jacob Bright, a man of property, much respected in Philadelphia before the war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning bills of William Bingham of Philadelphia, presented to them for acceptance; asks Franklin's advice.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An officer of the "Alliance" and nephew of Dr. Cooper writes on behalf of his brother, William Cooper, who is confined in Mill Prison; begs Franklin to procure his exchange.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Brosse, Claude-Valentine Millin de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of M. Wuibert, Lieut.-Col. in the service of America, who desires his share of the prize-money during his service with Commodore Jones. His plan to raise a troop for service in America, and why he was never able to carry it out.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for the wages and prize-money due him during his service on board the "Lexington," Capt. Henry Johnson.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Adams having gone to The Hague to meet M. le due de La Vauguyon, forwards the lists to Dr. Franklin in his stead.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Poellnitz, Baron Friedrich Karl Hans Bruno von.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His intention of embarking for Philadelphia with his family; reminds Franklin of his promise to furnish him with some recommendations.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Dr. Mason [Locke] Weems and his companion Mr. Manifold, who go to England on business; begs Franklin to favor them with the necessary passports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommends the dismissal of Mr.Francis Coffyn, American Agent at Dunkerque, who treats most dishonorably all Americans who appear before him; a few examples illustrating his treatment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His purchase of a new brig, the "Spry"; desires to send her to Boston under convoy of the "Alliance"; rates at which he is willing to carry public freight.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a passport for the vessel bound for Labrador; the ship, Captain, men and object are the same as when Franklin granted them the passport the year before at Mr.Hutton's request; intends to ask the same favor of M. de Castries.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a passport for the vessel bound for Labrador; the ship,Captain, men and object are the same as when Franklin granted them the passport the year before at Mr. Hutton's request; intends to ask the same favor of M. de Castries.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An ode to the United States; trusts Franklin will think this poem, as well as its two predecessors, worthy of being presented to his immortal Republic; wishes to guard his incognito, as he is obliged to give lessons in French to strangers, especially to the English.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: So far has not been fortunate in finding vessels to carry to America the goods assembled at Brest; desires to know Franklin's plans in this regard.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. The Captain of the "Alliance" has refused to go to Brest and will probably sail without the goods; relies wholly on the assistance of the Department of the Marine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sent to the Marquis de Castries the plan for an enterprise which cannot fail to prove distressing to England and highly important to America and France; desires to know as soon as the Marquis communicates it to Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging a signed statement that the frigate "Confederation," belonging to Congress; was captured on her voyage from St. Domingo to Philadelphia; the underwriters pretend that she was taken on leaving Philadelphia for another destination.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The length of her brother's illness and the loss she has sustained have prevented her going to see Franklin; wishes to know if he will receive her the next day and giver her some tea and bread and butter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to forward a certain sum to a soldier in the army of M. de Rochambeau; wishes to know if Franklin can give him an order on the town of York where the soldier is stationed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the receipt of Franklin's despatches; expects to set sail in a few hours.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Chaumont, Marie-Thérèse Jougues Le Ray de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was much disappointed that Franklin could not come and spend a few months here. The Benedictines who have a College here hoped that he would pay them a visit also. Her great friendship for him. Her Children often speak of him and long to see him again.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearers, Joseph Gole and Moses Howes, are both American sailors who escaped from English prisons and arrived in France in a destitute condition; furnished them with a sum of money on Franklin's account to pay the expenses of their journey.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laid Franklin's answer before the gentlemen to whom it was addressed; in spite of the negative given to the second article of their proposition, they are determined to emigrate; desires Franklin to procure them a certificate as a protection on the voyage over, and to forward certain of the requests to the Congress of Pennsylvania. Proceedings in the House of Commons tending towards ultimate peace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the custom-house duties on public goods. Terms for freighting his brig with public goods run high, but he can more than fill her with private freight at a higher price; if he were certain of having the public freight, he and Mr. Moylan would purchase a fine large ship; desires Franklin's advice. Will ship the seeds to Franklin at once.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fictitious plea couched in legal terms for Mme. Brillon de Jouy against Benjamin Franklin for not living up to the terms of their agreement of friendship to see each other as often as possible, to write to each other if separated, and to reply to all letters received from the other party.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Proc. Am. Philos. Soc., 1901, XL, 111.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was taken by the British ship "Recovery," carried into Ireland and thence conveyed to Mill Prison; writes for money and clothes.
(In duplicate.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Larwood and Van Hassett and Van Suchtelen. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Adams has accepted the fifty-one bills in question.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of money due Baron d'Arendt; begs Franklin to furnish him with a partial payment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging receipt of Franklin's remittance of £300 for the use of the prisoners; is that much in debt already, but will go on advancing the money. Announcing the expected retirement of the old Ministry, so hostile and so inimical to America; feels sure the rising Ministers will co-operate in any messures which may tend to peace; desires very much to hold the position of negotiator. Bill introduced into Parliament by Mr. [Edmund] Burke for the exchange of American prisoners; suggests certain steps to obtain the terms and conditions agreed upon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him to forward the enclosed letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The letter he received from Mlle. de Fay makes him hopeful of some day gaining the much-desired membership.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Soliciting Franklin's favor on behalf of M. Martin, who desires the position of American Consul at Bayonne.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reasons why he has not been to see Franklin for a long time. Enclosing a memoir which he believes will interest him, also a letter of ancient date which he was asked to deliver.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their escape from Kin(gs)ale Prison; account of the wretched condition there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the polite attentions shown him during his stay in Paris. Proposes embarking for America in the brigantine "Betsey," Capt. [Bernard] Gallagher; offers to carry any papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Bright, of Philadelphia, who made his escape from Forton Prison, is now detained at Brest by the Commandant; they have written requesting his and a Mr. Wood's discharge; they beg Dr. Franklin's assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering to furnish uniforms.
(In French.)
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. Will retain their offer, but at present has no purchases to make.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the distress among the escaped American prisoners; thinks no State should refuse the necessary meat and clothing to its servants; wishes the power given him to distribute such necessities; reported situation of the four hundred American prisoners at Kin(gs)ale, Ireland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Meyers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regarding Americans escaped from Irish prisons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presents him with a copy of his work.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Learned that Dr. Franklin was indisposed. Makes inquiries about his health.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The purchase of cloth in their province of Languedoc; number of articles he has furnished to the vessels at Bordeaux; hopes Franklin will honor him with his orders.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. William Vernon [Jr.] of Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A widow with four children; her eldest son desires to serve with the American troops; begs Franklin to procure him a passage over and a suitable rank in the army; his education at the Royal Military School.
(In French.)
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. "The armies of America full; not possible!"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to send some letters to Philadephia or Boston; many of his former letters miscarried. Congratulates him on the taking of St. Christopher.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The examination of his accounts by Mr. Barclay; wrote Congress praying them to adopt some just measure for the settlement of this affair; desiring Franklin to write them also on the subject. The changes which have lately taken place in London give hopes of a not distant peace.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Collections of New York Historical Society, 1890. Deane Papers, V, 80.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Chevalier Duvet de Contour, a young officer in the Marines, has begged of him some assistance; his story is that Franklin sent him to M. de Beaumarchais to receive the payment of the gratification always accorded to prisoners of war; M. de Beaumarchais being out of town has left him without resource; does not wish to be imposed upon, so asks Frankllin to confirm these statements.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His step-father is Mr. John Dixon, now living at Williamsburg; believes Franklin knows his parents, who desired him to make application for money on their account. Came to England to be operated upon for the stone, but since the death of a relative has been in great distress and knows not how to get home; turns to Franklin for assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that advice and assistance be given his nephew, Mr. Gurdon S. Mumford, who, in the absence of Mr. Silas Deane, is left without a protector.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: If the republic of America desires any statuary, asks that he be given the commission.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to go to Nantes in a few days; requests passports for himself and servant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In conformity with the King's orders, the officers of the Admiralty of Guadeloupe send Franklin two copies of the proceedings in regard to the prizes brought there by the American corsairs.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has paid Richard Bache, of Philadelphia, two hundred pounds in specie due to the widow Anne Catharine Höckl[er]in at Ebingen in Wurtemberg; begs that the enclosed letter be forwarded to her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The approaching departure of himself and his co-religionists for Pennsylvania where they hope to rival Manchester and Spitalfields in the manufacture of silk and other articles; asks for the necessary passports; his correspondence with Mr. Wyld. Written from London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of the ship the "Count de Grasse" with a prize; suggesting a speedy exchange of the prisoners taken. Desires to know whether it is true that Mr. Jay has been obliged to let the bills he accepted be protested for non-payment.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Rembau, Ferdinand de, and ----- Dupont d'Aisÿ. Donaueschingen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wish to serve in the American army; beg for Franklin's assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing that the boxes are ready.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring Franklin to become a member of the Academy of Sciences and Arts in Padus.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 197; Bigelow, VII, 434).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Takes the opportunity of his friend Joseph Walker, visiting Paris, to get some letters to America. Requests Franklin's acceptance of some poems [by William Cowper].

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conti, Louis-François-Joseph de Bourbon, comte de la Marche and prince de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a passport for his groom who goes to England to purchase horses.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just heard from Amsterdam that the bills accepted by Mr. Jay at Madrid are come back unpaid and protested; if Franklin desires they shall be paid and will send orders to that effect, he will notify the holders that if they send them back to Madrid, they will be surely paid.
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. Approves of M. Grand's suggestion; if the holders prefer, they can be paid at Paris or Amsterdam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Escaped from Forton Prison on the 13th of March; crave assitance to enable them to return to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that Franklin will write to M. de Castrics his willingness that the prisoners at St. Malo be liberated; there are three of them; Capt. Agnew and his father and Mr. Parker, a merchant; all from Virginia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends copy of memorial [2p.] he delivered to the Lords of the Admiralty, and note just received from Lord Shelburne [2p.]. Franklin may conclude the business done as soon as the official forms are got through with. Desires advice as to the transportation and victualling of the prisoners; situation of the prisoners in Ireland; can easily send them any remittance Franklin may be able to procure. Lord Shelburne's promises on behalf of the prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Believes the new Ministers will co-operate in any measures that may lead to peace. Plan to send him as a Peace Commissioner to Franklin; this idea given up; thinks Franklin will see a person of the first rank and of great consideration upon the same errand. The bearer of this letter will await Franklin's reply in regard to the exchange of prisoners; at the same time desires an answer to this private and confidential communication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends for the packets Franklin mentioned and feels honored with the trust confided to him; is confident of being well received in a country where every one honors one of the greatest men in the world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The representatives and the natives rose in arms so suddenly that he had not time to put Franklin's child and her own in a place of safety; nothing however has happened to the boy, and he hopes to obtain permission for him to leave the town very shortly; strangers have really nothing to fear.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sent Mr. [George] Fox the permission requested by Franklin, so that the books will be waiting him at the custom-house.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his kindness toward him as a representative of the company; expressing surprise at not receiving the necessary passports. Reasons why he thinks they are entitled to indulgence from any country where manufactures are wanted; desires him to recommend Congress to advance them a small sum, if their affairs require it; repayment guaranteed. Concerning a plan of two gentlemen in Derby to start a silk manufactory in Virginia, if they could be certain of being well received; desires Franklin's opinion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a proof of a third part of his essays, and reminds Franklin of his promise to inform him of his errors. Has read with pleasure the collection of Franklin's political memoirs.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His departure postponed until the following Sunday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apologizes for importuning him on behalf of Capt. Conyngham's crew; begs for an answer to allay the disquietude of the poor fellows.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending Dr. O'Connor; his experience; his desire to serve the United States, either in the army or in their hospitals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to wait on Franklin on Sunday, the day of his departure, and receive his commands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His grandson safe in Switzerland with M. [G. L. de] Marignac. Would have brought him herself, but permission to leave was refused to her and her children.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the original letter of [Edward] Nairne about the accident to the House of Industry at Heckingham which was struck by lightning, though furnished with eight conductors, on account of their being wrongly set up; steps he has taken to bring the matter before various societies; expects to return to London in a few days. Le Bègue de Presle will deliver to Dr. Franklin the complete work of [John] Miller (on the Linnacan System) which their late friend Dr. Fothergill desired to be forwarded to the [American] Philosophical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a sketch of an agreement relative to the exchange of American prisoners [2p.]; Franklin must either sign it or authorize him to do it. Transports will be ready in a short time to take the prisoners on board. Assured that a vessel will call at Kinsale to take on board the prisoners there. Suggests that Congress be acquainted, by the cartel ships, with the terms of exchange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Finds Franklin's name written on his door, and the hour three o'clock; waited in vain for his arrival; presumes some one has spoken of his mechanical contrivances; encloses a memoir of his work.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to go to America with his family and enter the service of the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot account for the non-arrival of the seeds. Is preparing a long letter with a detail of the obstacles in the way of American commerce in certain ports of France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His reasons for deciding to follow the sea; has been unfortunate up to this time but is now in a fair way to succeed; has just come up from Jamaica on parole but expects to be exchanged in a day or two; shall then return home where he has a good berth in a vessel bound for Europe; hopes Franklin will forgive him for not writing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending Mr. Anthony Lynch for the position of American Agent at the above prot.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has established, in his diocese of Languedoc, various manufactories in order to help the poor by giving them work; begs Frankliln to honor them with his orders for the United States. Reminds Franklin of their meeting in 1778 at the chateau of M. Bertin, the Minister.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearers of this are Whipple Crow and Benjamin Slocum, Americans taken on board the "Polly" and carried to Bristol; having made their escape, they arrived in France destitute of everything; drew on Franklin for money to take them to Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry to hear that Franklin's authority to grant their request has been recalled; desires that they be given the earliest opportunity to emigrate as they wish to be the first persons to arrive in the capacity of manufacturers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearers are John Kemp and Alex Findats, Americans, Captain and Lieutenant on board the "Greyhound"; their capture, imprisonment in England and subsequent escape; their arrival in France destitute; drew on Franklin for money to take them to Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosed letter to be forwarded to Boston; leaves soon for Chatillon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes for news of his son Julien; gives account of his movements from the time he entered the French navy up to the year 1780, when he ceased to hear from him; rumor that he is living in Boston.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering to send to Franklin a musket, pair of pistols, rifle and powderhorn, all of exquisite workmanship; thinks they would be a worthy present for General Washington.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for the return of his papers; feels sure that he has solid reasons for declining the execution of the plan; reasons why he will not fulfill Franklin's suggestion to render it successful elsewhere. His two girls go to town that day, one to stay with Mme. de la Marck, the other to visit Mme. Helvétius.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry that Franklin's interest in Mr. Wyld's undertaking was dampened by the delay in the payment of the bill upon himself; distress and confusion caused by Franklin's letter; certain of their friends have gone too far to retreat now. His plans for establishing a silk manufactory in America; success he has made of it in the past. If the country can yield a sufficient quantity of raw silk they can make it independent of Europe for those goods. If it cannot, then hopes that the Italian and East India markets may be opened in the meantime. For more than twenty years has set his heart on emigrating to America. If they do not go this season he wishes to go with his two sons as soon as possible. He thinks all the real liberty now or hereafter enjoyed in this island may be attributed to the noble heroes of North America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproaches him for not having answered any of his letters; particularly anxious to have his opinion upon the heat conducting quality of different metals; on this account, has retarded one year the publication of the book which he now sends. Attack made on his work by Dr. Priestley; convinced he can prove him wrong in his whole theory about the manner in which vegetables are subservient to the animal creation. Begs for news of Mr. Samuel Wharton who has large sums of his money to invest in trade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing him of the loss of her friend, Mme. Battier; has been obliged to take entire charge of her affairs; begs permission to send him a small box containing her friend's portrait, surrounded with diamonds, and a gold chain, which she wore up to her death; desires this box delivered to her friend's father, Mr. [Thomas] Ivers [at Boston].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the required permission for the books to be delivered at Rochefort without a visit from the Syndics.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His vessels depending on the Admiralty of France; desires some information on the subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for assistance; is in great pecuniary distress owing to an expensive law-suit and a long illness.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to go to America; begs Franklin to aid him with advice and recommendations.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends back the list to Franklin; the articles marked with a cross are the ones he desires.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Loder, First Physician to the Duke of Saxe-Weimar, and one of the first German anatornists. Congratulates him on the prospect of America's independence.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Barbançon, Augustin-Jean-Louis-Antoine du Prat, comte de. Varennes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his present of rare seeds.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Greatly pleased with a bust of Franklin he has just procured. His eldest son, now in his sixteenth year, has greatly improved in painting; while his thirteen-year-old boy shows great facility in learning. Refers Franklin to Mr. Whitefoord as regards his own situation.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II, 20.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have been long held prisoners in England. Beg for help to return to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to carry a packet into Paris for her father; unless he takes it in his own carriage, it would be stopped at the city gate.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Ollivier, ----- (notaire royale) and Le Guével, Th. Passy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a bill of exchange payable to Benjamin Franklin and drawn on Jonathan Nesbitt; the latter's refusal to accept it; account of the proceedings.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his adventures as an officer in the service of Congress; his long imprisonment and final escape; has not a farthing to his name and owes Mr. Moylan for his subsistence; desires his share of the prizemoney due him from the "Alliance," or a small advance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intention of Mr. James Moore of Scotland to enter into the American trade in France; his wish to take the oath of allegiance to the United States; sends one signed before witnesses. Begs for an answer about the American prisoners still boarding at his expense.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Professor of rhetoric in his College offered a prize for the best French translation of the famous Latin verse— "Eripuit coelo fulmen, sceptrumque tyrannis"; quotes his own translation which carried off the palm.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presumes Franklin forwarded the scheme of a bank to Mr. Morris, as he has since seen a Resolve of Congress to give Mr. Morris ample powers to carry such a scheme into execution. In Case of peace or truce, suggests that America institute a loan in England; discusses the advantages of such a step; its probable popularity in England; the question of security.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Major Van Braam, a native of Holland, who quitted the English army two years before, after thirty years' service; his intention to remove to France with his family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Establishment at Amsterdam of an emporium for goods from their manufactory of Gobelins; have appointed Paul Charlé their Agent for whom they beg a recommendation to Mr. Adams.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters received in this State and at Philadelphia, stating that France was at the bottom against America obtaining the fishery and territory in that great extent in which both are secured to America by the treaty; that the American Minister did not oppose this design, and that it was entirely owing to the firmness, sagacity and disinterestedness of Mr.Adams and Mr. Jay, that America obtained those important advantages. States that these letters are said to come from Mr. Adams, States that Mr. Adams wrote to Congress resigning his employments in Europe but intimated in a subsequent letter his readiness to continue them should he be appointed Minister to the Court of London.
(Press copy.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed, in part, in Works (Sparks, X, 6; Bigelow, VIII, 340).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. de la Grainehais who desires information relative to a deed of lands in Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His services in the American army since 1777; his capture by the English; his arrival in France and his destitute condition; desires assistance; names of five other prisoners who arrived with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's admission to the membership of the Academy of Padua shows how much he is esteemed in Italy; desires subscription to his "Complete Collection of the Most Beautiful Selections from Italian Poetry."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mistake made by M. Leleu; these unhappy Americans are able to prove that they do not come from English prisons; hopes Franklin will give them the desired assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explaining the mistake be made in saying six Americans had arrived from English prisons; true account of their capture and arrival in France; can vouch for their not being English spies in disguise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing fourteen bills which he begs Franklin to accept and return.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their request for a letter of recommendation to Mr. Adams on behalf of Mr. Paul Charlé.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In accordance with his orders, sends him the twenty-six volumes of the Collections of Ancient Roman Authors and one volume of the Greek.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes the exchange of prisoners will take place the following week. The letters to go to Congress by the cartel vessels must be forwarded at once. Presented Franklin's acknowledgments to the "noble personage" for his kindness and attention to Americans. Pleasing prospect of peace. Messages from Drs. Priestley and Price, and Messrs. Jones and Paradise. Money due him for disbursements to prisoners. Desires Franklin to send a special messenger at his expense with earliest news of whether there will or will not be a Congress to treat on terms of pacification.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their friends have gone too far to retreat; begs Franklin to do the most he can towards rendering their passage over safe. His views on the establishment of a silk manufactory in America.
