scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An officer on board the "Bon Homme Richard," Commodore Paul Jones; in the engagement with the "Serapis," was so seriously wounded that he has become a hopeless invalid; begs for his share of the prizemoney to alleviate the situation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the pass and letters of recommendation. Misunderstood the conference between Franklin and Mr. Wyld; thinks the latter was perhaps too sanguine. His intention of persuading his friends in the country, if possible, to delay their departure till peace is established; if they are resolved to go, will risk everything to go with them. Account of his interview with Mr. [Henry] Laurens who, owing to the delicacy of his situation, could not comply with his request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin's acceptance of the enclosed volumes as memorials of his cordial esteem and respect.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is greatly flattered that Franklin will accept the dedication of his general thesis on philosophy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Important services rendered by him to the American cause; hopes Franklin will permit an introduction by his friend, M. Grand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him an account of the sale of his "Topographical Description of America," in order that the poor widow Barry may receive her just dues . Hoped to have been legally authorized to communicate with Franklin on the subject of peace. Sees he will never be employed in Europe on account of the objection to him of one person.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed, in part, in Hale's Franklin in France II, 22.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the miniature of the late Mrs. Battier which Miss Murray, of Ghent, sent to Franklin's care; desires him to forward it to Mr. Thomas Ivers at Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report of America having declared war against Portugal; if this is true, would like a commission for the "Spry" to cruize against the Portugese. News of a bloody engagement between the Comte de Grasse and Mr. Rodney; advantage doubtful. Message from Capt. Jon. Coffin of Nantucket.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desire of about one hundred poor tradesmen and husbandmen to settle in America; having no money to pay their passage, they propose to indent as servants for a certain term; the owner of the ship unwilling to accept them in this manner without being sure of the approval of Congress; can assure him that there is not a convict or felon amongst them.
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. Contrasting the condition of the poor in America with those in other lands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring some information about a young man whose mother is distracted with grief over his reported death in York, Virginia; begging Franklin to ascertain the truth of this rumor and any other details obtainable.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending certain letters and apologizing for their detention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolution instructing the Minister at the Court of Versailles to take immediate measures for liquidating the accounts between the United States and that Court and report a state thereof to Congress; also appointing a Commissioner to liquidate and settle the accounts of all the servants of the United States who have been entrusted with the expenditure of public moneys in Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is about to send Capt. John Moultson, an American, on a new cruize with the schooner "Sophia"; hearing that war was declared by the United States against Portugal, writes for a commission of war for the Captain so that he may cruize under American colors against the enemies of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a bill of exchange for acceptance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning M. de Castries's request for a ship to be freighted at Nantes for the service of the United States; must have further orders. Urges some action as regards the American prisoners.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lacepède, Bernard-Germain-Etienne de La Ville-sur-Illon, comte de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His regret at leaving Paris without having paid his respects to Franklin; his first volume on physics about to appear.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a passport to be issued to his cousin at Nantes for the latter's vessel "Nostra Signora."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin to give them a letter of protection for their vessel "Nostra Signora" bound from Nantes to San Domingo.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes that the little monument he has wished to erect to the memory of Miss MacRea will prove acceptable to her friends.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. Boudon, an orphan, left to the care of a tutor; enticed away from this protector by relatives who desired his small fortune; persuaded by them to go to America; his adventures at St. Eustatius where he lost everything; his arrival in Philadelphia; unless Mr. Wharton has protected him, his tutor and friends fear the worse; begs Dr. Franklin to ascertain his whereabouts and hasten his return.
(In French. See XXV, 103.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for listening to his relative's request [for a passport for the "Nostra Signora"].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Postponing the King's reception of the Ambassadors and Foreign Ministers to the 8th of June, 1782.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His son desires to enter the American service; begs Franklin to procure him the position of officer in the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Loss of certain bills of exchange; begs Franklin to refuse them if presented.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommends that the terms of peace should be marked by generous language and humane measures; is sure that no liberality will meet with a repulse. He may hear of Mr. [Henry] Lauren's strange behavior from Mr. Oswald. Has given orders for shipping £6000 in goods to America; increase of emigration there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging receipt of £200; gratitude of the prisoners for the kindness shown them. Departure of the three hundred prisoners from Portsmouth; rumors of their being riotous and ungovernable unfounded. There will be upwards of seven hundred prisoners in Plymouth including those arrived from Kinsale. Convinced that certain persons in power mean to walk fairly and uprightly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his friend Mr. Henry Mitchell of Boston just arrived on the ship "Alexander" from Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Dr. Franklin on his success in the American cause. Encloses a letter to his son, the General, with the request to forward. Complains that his son has not answered for a year his letters. Would like to hear of him before he dies.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Smith, Joseph. Cape Saint Nicholas, Haiti

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a prize captured by him in his brig, "Lady Grune", commissioned by Congress; the sloop was judged and condemned as a good prize to the captors; begs Franklin, on receipt of the enclosed papers (1p.), to order the money paid him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Foy who intends staying near Paris in order to perfect himself in the French Language.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account received of M. de la Luzerne's house in Philadelphia having been struck by lightning; the accident imputed to the want of Dr. Franklin's lightning-rods. General Knox and Mr.Gouverneur Morris appointed by Gen. Washington to negotiate an exchange of prisoners. Mr. Gadsden elected Governor of South Carolina by declined serving; British property in that State confiscated; the reason given. Account of the action on the Delaware between the American vessel "Hyder Ally" and the British "General Monk", sloop of war, which ended in the latter's being taken. Just recovering from an attack of epidemic influenza.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a copy of XXIV, 146 (see p. 463); Baron d' Arendt had the misfortune to be captured and carried into New York; being released on parole he obtained the above copy, having lost the original.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of the "Don Galvez" from Salem, which she left December 1st.; at that time, M. de. Vandreuil with the fleet remained at Boston and did not expect to sail untill the end of the month. Fresh cruelties committed by the Indians on the back settlements near Sunbury.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to forward the enclosed letter for Baron de Steuben at Philadelphia.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Jacques Rocquette, T.A. Elsevier, and Fréres Rocquette. Rotterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him not to accept certain bills drawn on them by their friends Curson and Gouverneur, at St. Eustatius, and the cause; concerning certain bills of Congress in their possession; desire advice how to procure their payment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to peruse the enclosed letter [3p.] before forwarding it to Mr. Samuel Wharton. The mercantile undertaking he engaged in with that gentleman; particular interest he therefore takes in his honesty; not rich enough to bear such a great loss; desires Franklin's opinion. The Emperor still hoping to see Franklin in Vienna as Minister in the ensuing General Congress; desires to know whether his hopes are well grounded and if Lord Shelburne and Mr. Fox will declare them a free people. Hears Franklin has a letter half-written to him; begs for it unfinished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires further instructions about shipping the public stores.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a French ship which offers to take the public stores. American prisoners finally gone; all their expenses paid by him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin has doubtless heard of the epidemic which still afflicts Toulouse; all the students have left the University; the thesis, of which Franklin graciously accepted the dedication, must therefore be given up for that year.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his friend, M. de Kurouski, who desires to enter the service; the enclosed memoir [1p.] gives account of his military experiences.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The company in the neighborhood of Manchester have gone too far to retreat; uncertain whether to go with them to America; knows he is capable of conducting with success linen, cotton or silk manufactures; desires to know whether it would not be better to get men of property in America to join him as partners in the concern.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Jacques Rocquette, T.A. Elsevier, and Fréres Rocquette. Rotterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a vessel of theirs, which was captured by the "Vengeance"; complains of the treatment of the officers and the confiscation of the goods; begs his intercession to obtain the restitution of the cargo.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Waited upon the Comte de Vergennes with Franklin's commands. A meeting to be arranged with Mr. [William Wyndham] Grenville; promises to acquaint Franklin with the result in case he cannot be present.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 337).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Robert Milligan, of Cecil Co., Maryland, who has been studying law in England and designs visiting Paris on his return to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter from Saussine [XXV, 78 1/2, see p. 481] and another to himself from St. Etienne [XXV, 80]; begs him to discover the whereabouts of the young man in question [M. Boudon].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Large size paper necessary to carry out Franklin's orders for the books; sends a sample of the kind needed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a passport for Mrs. Adams, wife of an American Captain, who goes to join her husband at Amsterdam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his friend, Dr. Lister, who is much esteemed in Edinburgh and London; any civility shown him will be much appreciated by himself as well as Franklin's dissenting friends in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing copy of a letter from Brest; no doubt that the prize in question belongs to the captors; begs Franklin to state the case to M. de Castries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Cephas Dawes, of Pennsylvania, who settled as a merchant in the West Indies previous to the commencement of the war; a warm friend to the cause of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ordered to the above sea-port by his physican in England; finds he cannot remain without a passport or permission from Paris; begs Franklin's assistance in the matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter from Mr. Ingen Housz.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring some news of his brother, who embarked for America in 1777 with the Count de Brétigny.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding papers respecting two prizes brought in by the "Revolution," privateer. Account of some Americans who escaped from English prisons; arrived in Brest, were sent to L'Orient on bread and water, and are now in jail.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the money paid to Capt. De Freÿ.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin his letters just received from Boston. Settlement of their business with Mr. Barclay. Decision of the senior member of their firm to retire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received Franklin's condemnation of the prize " Mary of London," captured by the "Revolution" of Salem; desires judgement to enable him to sell the prize "St. Pierre" of St. André, recaptured from the enemy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposition for peace. Enclosure concerning emigration.
Queries respecting the grounds of emigration and settlement in America.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 355).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if he has received directions from Robert Morris to pay what is due to him, and when he may draw on him for the money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the right of the French Admiralty to confiscate an American prize; importance of a line from Franklin on this subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Major Shirlume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On behalf of Mr. Bonneau, desires to know when Franklin will be visible the following afternoon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has had great pleasure in obtaining the portrait Franklin desired; Madame la Marquise de la Fayette desires its return as soon as possible; she has perfect faith in the care Franklin will take of it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending an English work addressed to his care by M. de Crevecoeur.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Decree giving full power and authority to his Minister and Secretary of State, Count de Vergennes, to conduct negotiations with the Minister Plenipotentiary from the United States with a view to ascertain and determine the amounts of money advanced to the latter and the conditions under these advances were made.
(In French. Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On account of his interest in the young man and his attachment to the family, sends the enclosed memoir concerning M. Penet.
(In French.)

M. Penet, Aide-de-camp to Gen. Washington; his commission in Europe to purchase merchandise for the American army; the fidelity and intelligence with which he acquitted himself; before Congress could advance the needed funds, everything he possessed was seized to meet the payments; request that the account may be adjusted and young man enabled to return to France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His service in America; his congé received after his long imprisonment in Savannah; his sojourn in Switzerland to recover his health; his wish to return; desires Dr. Franklin to procure him an exchange.
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. Has no orders to furnish officers with the means of going to America; such exchanges as he desires are made in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. [Benjamin] Green, an artist of distinguished merit in mezzotints and engraving.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a statement of Mr. Morris's account; instead of contracting new engagements it is necessary to find the means to meet the old ones.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Embarked for America as one of the Hessian auxiliaries; witnessed many engagements; on his arrival in South Carolina made the lovely Nancy Elliot's acquaintance; induced by the promise of her hand, he asked for his dismissal with the intention of entering the Continental service; obtained his discharge, but was sent back to England and thence to Germany; is now free to accept an appointment in the American army as well as the hand of the fair Nancy; begs Franklin to procure him the former.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending English paper of a later date than the ones he delivered the previous day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Are fitting out a brig for Philadelphia called the "Grace Bermuda," for which they desire a commission; have on board a large quantity of State goods which Mr. Thomas Barclay was embarrassed to ship on reasonable terms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to enter the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The capacity of the ship "Argo" both for receiving freight and passengers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the work sent him by Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed that the sailors Franklin wrote about to William Moore and Co., are at liberty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers Franklin to Mr. Joly for the reason of his detention; general belief in his innocence; solicits Franklin's good offices. Desires to know if Commodore Gillon has arrived in America; will probably have to return to that country to obtain redress for the injury done him by Gillon. His enlistment in the American army caused him to be disinherited in favor of two younger brothers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to be appointed Consul-General for the United States at Trieste, Fiume and other Austrian ports on the Adriatic; at present serves the States-General in the same capacity; doubts not that he will be able to hold both Consulates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was connected with the house of Penet, D'Acosta and Co. until their dealings forced him to relinquish all connection with them; desires Franklin to procure him some position.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergennes, Charles Gravier, comte de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Doubts as to the sincerity of the British Ministry in proposing a negotiation of peace.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 373, Bigelow, VIII, 136.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reasons why his petition to Franklin, Count d'Aranda and the French Ministry failed; the more the Irish are ill-treated, the more emigrants will flock to America and France to fill the armies; their miserable situation in France and the way they are despised and ill-treated; if he returns and makes known these facts the armies and navy of England may gain many sincere supporters; desires to know if anything will be done for him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosed letter to be forwarded to Mrs. Strange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a letter of recommendation to Mr. Adams on behalf of their Agent, M. Paul Charlé.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enthusiasm for the American cause. Prospect of peace. State of the credit and manufactories. Messages to Franklin from Mrs. Stevenson and Mrs. Hewson. Possibility of her coming to Paris or of Franklin being summoned to London. Hears that her son [Joseph Wright] is painting Franklin's portrait.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II, 216.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the prize "Anthony" taken by the brig "Don Galvez"; desires the necessary papers forwarded to them.

A. E. by Dr. Franklin. "The 'Anthony' from Africa, a brigantine, Capt. George Bevans, of London, taken by the 'Don Galvez,' Capt. Silas Jones, of Salem in New England, the 24th of June, brought into l'Orient."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Read with pleasure the work of M. de Crevecoeur; thinks the author is indebted to Franklin for much of his information; moralizes on ideas engendered by reading the book.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing that the King will not see the Ambassadors and Foreign Ministers on the following Tuesday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a commission for their ship "Argo" owned by Samuel R. Irwitt and Co. of America.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Poncelin de La Roche-Tilhac, Jean-Charles, abbé. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for certain details needed to finish his work on the present condition of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Very anxious to know Franklin's opinion of Abbé Raynal's History of the Revolution in America, in order that he may translate the work into German.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their right to dispose of some powder, taken in a prize consigned to them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears that his letter of the 17th ult. miscarried; encloses a copy (2p.) with the memoir relative to M. Penet [XXV, 119, see p. 488].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the birth of a daughter. Passage money to America wholly the Captain's prequisite; thinks it could be got a little cheaper than twenty-five guineas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him to send the enclosed letter to the Town Council of Philadelphia so that it may be sure to reach Mr. Theedore Mieger.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests the forwarding of the enclosed requisition of Theodore Mieger, to the authorities in Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a new copy of his plan; his present fearful situation enhanced by seeing his daughter obliged to share it; losses he sustained during his imprisonment in England, and his unfortunate ship-wreck at Havre-de-Grace; begs for some assistance; promises to repay.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending several models of tombstones. Offers him as a slight mark of his homage, the statue of Pierre Corneille, a copy of the one executed for the King.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In receipt of the most heart-rending letters from the Count de Benyowski, who left for America with letters from Franklin, confident that Congress would give him employment; desires an explanation of such conduct as he has met with from Congress; the Countess is in despair.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a letter from Tristram Dalton, Esq., of Newburyport, relative to payment for the loss of the brigantine, "Fair Play"; death of his new-born daughter; low state of Mrs. William's health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Nat[haniel] Barrett and Mr. Frazer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him to accept the enclosed bills belonging to an industrious black man in his service. Took on board the "Amazon" four priests, subjects of the King of Sardinia, who were going as missionaries to Quebec; desires to know if they can be held as British subjects and exchanged for four Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing for Franklin what he wished; leaves it to him whether the account is natural or not. Will bring the lady they spoke of to visit Franklin; interested in her; inclined to credit her story.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the History of Lord North's Administration. Desires him to grant an interview to M. Sobe, who desires a commission from Congress for the merchandise the United States intend to buy in Guyenne.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urges his former request for an exchange; needs this to enable him to join his regiment in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his letter containing the explanation of the stroke of lightning at Cremona, as well as his favor of the 4th ult. Reasons for thinking there will be a general Congress at Vienna. Tempted to spend his declining years with Franklin in America. Reflections induced by Franklin's experiment with wires. Franklin's remark that it was to the interest of all Europe to prevent a federal connection between Great Britain and the American Free States; gave this extract with some of his reflections thereon to the Emperor. If M. Le Bègue [de Presle] is too busy to take charge of the impression of his book, intends confiding it to M. Le Roy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transcribing XXV, 114 (see p. 487), to which he has received no reply; again requests to know whether Franklin has received these instructions from Mr. [Robert] Morris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Samuel Mansfield, Captain in the service of the United States, who escaped from an English prison and arrived in France is destitute of means. Furnished him on Franklin's account with the necessary sum to defray his expenses to Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him to forward the four packets by four different vessels.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has served France in all the wars in Germany; desires to see America and to fight under Gen. Washington; begs Franklin to grant him some military employment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin, as a personal favor, to release the English Captain, Henry Asgill.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II, 209.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking that the annexed letter [XXV, 166] be forwarded to the President of Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The report confirmed of her husband's death; expects to return to her father and family in London; offers to undertake any commission for Franklin. Never expects to see Philadelphia again.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know the success of his application to the Spanish Ambassador for a passport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has fitted out a few ships and expects to sail in four or five weeks; happy to execute any commands with which he may entrust him. Hears that he has several anchors at his disposal; applies for one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has returned the papers relative to the consular powers; has only one suggestion to make; thinks the Consuls and Vice-Consuls ought to be left at liberty to carry on what commerce they please.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his kindness. Waiting for permission to reenter England and embark for New York; desires the necessary passport for leaving France with his son, two daughters and a domestic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Departure for France of Mr. [Gerard van de] Brantsen; Minister Plenipotentiary of a Holland to treat with M. de Berkenrode concerning the preliminaries of a general peace.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His kinsman [William Cooper], whom he feared was a prisoner, has arrived here with many others of his countrymen. Fears the defeat of Count de Grasse in the West Indies will encourage the Court of London to continue the war. Current reports and disposition of the British forces. The Marquis de Vaudreuil, with thirteen ships of the line and several frigates, arrived from the West Indies to repair; every courtesy extended to the Marquis. The "Magnifique" of 74 guns went aground and it is feared is lost. It is proposed with general unanimity that Congress give the 74 gen ship at Portsmouth to the King to supply the place of the "Magnifique." An English fleet of 25 sails of the line arrived near the Chesapeake. Never approved of Mr. [John] Temple's going to England and to Lord North to oppose the representations of Galloway. Mr. Temple claims great merit for procuring and sending to this country the Hutchinson letters. To this Judge [James] Sullivan opposes your advertisement in a London paper and a letter of Mr. Temple in which he declares he had nothing to do with them. Recommends Mr. Jonathan Amory of Boston to his attention. Is now residing in Brussels. He took the oath of allegiance to the King but now desires to return to this country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the detention at Rochefort of the vessels, "Achilles", "Maurice" and "Maria Theresa" loaded with merchandise for the United States; Captain of the "Maria Theress" wishes that part of his cargo be removed, as he fears damage; such an operation sure to be expensive; begs Franklin to take some action in the matter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His services in America since 1778, as Aide-de-camp to Col. Armand; only returned to France to re-establish his health; wishes to go back; begs Franklin to present the enclosed memoir [1p.] to the Minister, that he may obtain the commission of Captain and a donation for his trip over.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a catalogue of the "Marquis de la Fayette's" cargo just received; sends it back with certain notes and marks. Mrs. Williams much better.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies to Franklin to obtain a debt owing him by M. de Monneron, Engineer in the service to the United States; his embarrassing situation, due to the loss of such a considerable sum of money; encloses copy [1p.] of the two notes of indebtedness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advices received from England oblige him to start on his journey within forty-eight hours; begs Franklin to send his passport to Calais where it will overtake him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kindness of the Prince of Robecq; begs that measures may be taken to obtain his release.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No monument worthy of Franklin's greatness; the objects which have aided him in his career will assume to the possessor a precious importance; an engraving of Franklin, a pair of spectracles and one of the pens which traced the glory and safety of America -- these represent his heart's desire; will Franklin refuse them to him?
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Innocent of the charge for which he has been confined during three months; had nothing to do with the arrest of the Captain of the Dutch corsair; persuaded if Franklin explains the affair to Comte de Ségur, there will be an end to his imprisonment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acquainting Franklin with the distressing situation of their husbands, Capt. Edward Macatter and Capt. John Kelly ( alias Grumly); the former a prisoner in London, the latter in Dublin; money owing them from the sale of prizes by John Torris; the villainy and deceit of Torris; if the liquidation of the prizes could be obtained, something might be done; beg Franklin to intercede on their behalf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a commission to command a letter of marque for Capt. Thomas Bell, commander of the "Renette" bound from l'Orient to Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a packet of clothing for Madame Williams at Nantes; his carriage commodious; will bear anything Franklin would like to send.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin may remember him by the campaign into Canada; begs that the enclosed letters may be forwarded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At Mrs. [Ann] Evans's request, encloses letters and bill of exchange for her daughter, Mrs. [Ann] Loviel; Mrs. Evans's strong desire to have her daughter back in Virginia; has promised to pay Mrs. Loviel's passage to the Captain of any vessel who will take her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the desire of Mrs.[Ann] Evans, asks Dr. Franklin to assist her daughter, Mrs. [Ann] Loviel, to return from France to Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a physician from Vienna and a fellow-traveler of Dr. Ingen Housz in his last journey to England; desires to communicate a plan for a code of penal laws, which might prove useful to any nation.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the birth of a daughter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a copy of the Manual of Epictetus, in Greek, which he is at present printing.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Dr. Burrows; to her great regret, he and his family are going to England; any attention Franklin may show him she will consider as a personal favor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging the acceptance of a bill of exchange.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Nathaniel Nelson; his reason for going to Ireland; begs Franklin to grant him the necessary passport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obtained from the sculptor he mentioned to Franklin two drawings of fair-sized medals, and two designs of the same subject from a painter of his acquaintance; desires to know when and where he can show them to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seconding the request of Captains [Alexander] Cain, [James] Josiah and [Richard] Deale, of the ships "St. James," "Lady Washington" and "Queen of France."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposing a speedy method of exchanging a number of prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for a passport for a vessel sailing from Ostend.
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. Has no authority to give such passports, and if he had, it would be no of use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ordered by Congress to prepare and lay before them a state of the pay, rations and subsistence of the officers and men in the European armies; begs Franklin to furnish him with such details concercing the armies of France, Spain and Germany. Fine condition of the American army; compliment paid the troops by Count [de] Rochambeau; splendid conduct of the French troops; friendship existing between the two allied armies.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 413).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. de Villiers has constructed a watch on original lines; desires to place this invention before him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the American supplies at Brest and the scarcity of proper vessels in which to carry, them; does not advise shipping any of them as long as there is a probability of the Court of France sending them; necessity of getting them off in time for the next campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the daily consumption of wine, beer, etc., at Dr. Franklin's table.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promising to dine with Franklin; sending the letter relative to Capt. Blair; hope a favourable answer to Gen. Conway's request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning bills of exchange.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found an account of Père Barletti's pamphlet in an Italian journal, Hopes Franklin has not laid aside his reflections on the new fire-place which has the form of a vase or urn. Trusts his admonition will have some effect on Mr. Samuel Wharton and his son. Message sent by Sir Robert Murray Keith to the Dutch Envoy at Vienna, to the effect that seven of the thirteen American provinces had submitted to the English government; desires to know whether there is any foundation for such a report. New and important discoveries he has made in vegetables. Experiment of burning wire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All his attempts to recover his sacrificed property from the German vultures have failed. Expects to leave shortly for Venice where he will be happy to receive Franklin's commands; thinks he might be useful in sounding the general disposition of the Venetian state towards America, and in bringing them over to the support of their sister-republic. Grants of land made to him in New York and Georgia. His belief in legal and equal liberty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had the honor of dining with Franklin four years before, on the eve of her departure for Italy; has just returned, bringing a letter in her favor from the Queen of Italy to the Queen of France; expects to go to Passy the following day for her answer, and begs permission to spend the time she may have to wait at Franklin's house.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Ambassador of the Emperor of H.R.E

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will forward the package addressed to Mr. Ingen Housz, which Franklin has sent him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his of the 30th ult., with the enclosures for Captains [Alexander] Cain, [James] Josiah and [Richard] Deale, who are extremely obliged. Begs Franklin to order everything done to accelerate the speedy condemnation of the prize ship "Lion." Three American ships of force in port, which will sail for Philadelphia between the 15th and 20th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heard with great concern of his illness. Entertaining time she had at Bath.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to use his interest with Congress to obtain indemnity for them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Impossibility of forwarding the supplies at the expense of the French Court; suggests various channels by which they may be shipped. News of the arrival at Boston of Capt. Grinnell with 2,500 suits of clothing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After five months of travel and work has returned to the Countess of Forbach; regret to hear his health is not what it was; delighted to hear of the rich prizes lately brought in at l'Orient.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making a collection of the laws of the United States; his first volume presented to the Due de la Rochefoucauld, who approved his design of publishing a second volume; desires permission to copy certain documents which may not be in his collection and to submit the order and plan of his work to Franklin's criticism and advice.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Glad Franklin is better; can't afford to lose him yet. Has been promised that the 120 American prisoners should be sent to l'Orient as soon as a vessel could be got ready. Money he advanced to Capt. Houston before he left Forton Prison; desires to know if the bill will be honored in l'Orient; if so, wishes the money sent to Mr. Wright for the picture which he is expecting. Question of the French Ministry continuing the war after America's claims have been adjusted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending four letters of recommendation for Sir [Edward] Newenham.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had the misfortune to be captured by the "Intrepid" while serving as captain of the sloop "Retaliation"; at present is on parole; begs Franklin to loan him ten or twelve pounds; his father is Jedediah Preble of Falmouth, and one of the Council of Boston.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Washington, George. Head Quarters, State of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favors of April 2d and 8th delivered to him by the Comte de Ségur and the Prince de Brogile; promise of attention to these distinguished young noblemen. Reasons for fearing a continuance of their present troubles. Condition of military affairs.
(Duplicate.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, IX, 421; Bigelow, VIII, 199).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring news of Frantz Siegfried de Wutsen, a resident of Magdeburg, who passed from the Prussian to the American service and embarked for the United States in 1777; since then his family have heard nothing of him; importance of ascertaining whether he be alive or dead.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring him to forward the enclosed packet; it is the property of M. St. Jean de Crevecoeur, who desires particularly to know if Franklin received a work he sent him on the troubles and disasters of America.
(In French.)
E. by M. de Musset-Pathay concerning the Comtesse d'Houdetot.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Housberg, head of a cast-iron foundry, whose proposals they trust will meet with Franklin's approval.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obliged to suspend payment and to go into retirement; is trying to come to some agreement with his crediters.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his generous section on behalf of the widow Höcklerin; desires to know how she is to obtain the sum of money and how much it will be in the coin of the Realm.
(In Fench.)
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. The sum is in the hands of M. Frederic Grand; Mrs. Höcklerin can draw it in such a manner as she shall be advised.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the estate of Johann Gottfried Schmidt. His son, Johann Friedrich, settled as preacher in Germantown, Pennsylvania, 15 years ago.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The unfortunates who served on the "Revenge," Capt. Conyngham, disappointed again and again in the hope of obtaining their share of the prize-money; in danger at present of being turned into the street; begs Franklin to intercede with Mr. Richard Bache to procure their just dues.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Capt. Harrison's protest against the misconduct of the commander of the frigate "Em[e]r(o) [au]d[e]," whose desertion at a critical moment caused his ship the "Jolly Tar" to be taken by the English and carried to New York; detailed account of the whole affair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oath of office as Secretary of the Commissioners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Return Capt. Houston's bill accepted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him the answer received from the Commandant of Lyons. [See XXVI, 48] in regard to their letter of recommendation to Sir [Edward] Newenham.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will wait upon Franklin the following Saturday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring him to lend them the two volumes of Chinese memoirs.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Blancherie, Claude-Mammès de Pahin Champlain de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires the death certificate of M. de Troye, Lieutenant in Pulaski's Legion, who died at Charlestown and was buried there on December 21st, 1779; also wishes Mr. [John] Adam's address.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been asked to write an eulogy on the late Sir John Pringle, to be read at their next public meeting [of the Royal Society of Medicine]; knowing this celebrated physician to have been a great friend of Franklin applies to him for details of his life and works.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminds him of the circumstances of the institution of the University of Dartmouth in New Hampshire; Dr. [Eleazar] Wheelock's indefatigable labors to civilize and christianize the native Indians; this work interrupted by the war; Dr. Wheelock's son [John] now the president, who, in order to bring the institution to perfection, is authorized by the trustees to solicit benefactions in France and Holland; recommends him to Franklin's assistance and patronage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A subscriber to their encyclopaedia of 39 volumes; by this time he will have received all the volumes, therefore they beg him to send the price of the subscription to M. Grand, banker in Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears that the British Janus does not intend to deal fairly by the Kingdom of Ireland in the expected treaty of peace; wishes to know if Ireland is particularly mentioned; has written a public letter to the men of Ireland advising them to demand this of their King; encloses a copy [1 p.]; has delayed sending it until he hears from Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nothing very interesting in Irish polities; Lord Temple more assiduous and more prodigal in offers to corrupt the Parliament than any of his predecessors. The British Ministry determined to push the raising of 5,000 fencibles. Respect and admiration for Franklin. Expects to convey to Ireland the valuable present of Franklin's bust, from which he expects to have many models made.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending Mr. John Christopher Hornbostel for Chief Consul for Provence and Languedoc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delay in exchange caused by the Goverment having no ships for that service. Asked to propose to Franklin to exchange Lieut.-Col. Tarleton for two Captains of American privateers; England's attitude in hitherto absolutely refusing to acknowledge any rank in Americans taken and brought into England; thinks this proposition is due to the Heir-Apparent at the instigation of a beautiful lady who bestows her favors occasionally on both him and Lieut.-Col.----- ; Mr. [Henry] Laurens returned from Bath and intends going to Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him the enclosed letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served on the "Bon Homme Richard" under Paul Jones, when he captured the "Serapis"; demands his share of the prize-money.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The independence of the United States will shortly be recognized by all the powers of Europe; offers his services at Augsburg, in matters of politics, commerce, and jurisprudence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An Agent or chargé d'Affaires for the United States will be needed at every large German city. Offers his services.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know if Franklin received a letter from M. Filangieri of Naples, the author of an essay on legislation, 1 who wishes to merit the esteem of the greatest philosopher of the New World.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing the Comte de Rechteien.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed that History of the Revolution has been written in America; desires to know where he may obtain a copy; being prevented from fighting for the Colonies, wishes to render them a service by translating this history into French.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have been defrauded by M. P. Penet; the merchandise supplied at his request was destined for Virginia, therefore they apply to Franklin, as the representative of the United States in France, to obtain payment for these goods.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Papers and letters relative to complaints of the treatment of British prisoners in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging his assistance and protection in recovering the rights and possessions of an unfortunate family; he knows their losses too well to need an account of them; aware that Lord Shelburne has authorized Mr. [Samuel] Vaughan to back her application, but would rather rely on the justice of her cause; adopts Franklin for the guardian of William Penn's grandchildren.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His arrest and imprisonment on the charge that his crew pillaged a neutral vessel; disclaims any knowledge of it; declares the orders on his vessel ["The Eclipse"] were very strict against plundering neutral vessels; thinks a captain cannot always prevent such unlawful proceedings; comes of a reputable family in New London; feels his character much injured by such treatment; implores Franklin's intercession on his behalf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As the director of a school intended for young noblemen, begs Franklin to recommend it to the Americans who intend educating their children in Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Saw Franklin's grandson and his companion Jeanet; praises both boys.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II. 227.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Anxious about Mr. Samuel Wharton's principles; cannot believe his crime is a worse one than a neglect to write; Dr. Bancroft's behavior inspires him with the most unfavorable suspicions; reasons why he can ill afford to lose any more money; begs Franklin to obtain from Mr. Bancroft, Mr. Wharton's original letters, look them over and report on them. Result of his controversy with Dr. Priestley; will follow Franklin's good advice about abstaining from polemics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging a passage to America for a clever youth called Minet; the sooner he leaves paris the better; his ability will enable him to become a printer or engage in any other work.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Captain Geo[rge] Meggs, taken prisoner on his passage from New York to London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his favor of November 12th with the welcome contradiction of the reports circulated against America. Dr. Bancroft's letter fails to clear up the matter and Mr. Samuel Wharton's silence remains inexcusable; suspicious nature of certain circumstances. Experiment for burning wire. Cautions Franklin against taking too much medicine; recommends rubbing and exercise.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed, in part in Works (Sparks, VI, 448).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes of a young man who desires to go to America and establish himself in commerce; his family too poor to pay his expenses; thought Franklin might get him his passage free.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning certain bills of exchange sold to Mr. John Augustus Byrne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The [Masonic] Brotherhood of the Nine Sisters desire to send a deputation to Franklin to felicitate him on the approaching peace.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to pay his respects to Franklin and to inform him of the audience he had with the King, in his capacity of Minister Plenipotentiary of the United Provinces.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his intention of waiting upon Franklin the following day.
(In French.)
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. Regrets that he is obliged to be absent from Passy that morning.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Saw in Freeman's Philadelphia Journal, among the names of those who have forfeited their estates, two John Taylors; in great anxiety lest his property should fall under one of them; reasons for his residence in Bath; left America in 1762; his warm attachment to that country; begs Franklin to point out to him what methods he should pursue to reverse the forfeiture, if it has taken place, or prevent it in the future.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminds Franklin of their old friendship. Refers to his history and that of Barbadoes and of having fallen a sacrifice to the accursed politics of England; the hurricane completed his ruin; friends he has made in France who hope to interest M. de Vergennes in his behalf; hopes Franklin will co-operate in any scheme for his advantage. Interview he had with Mr. Laurens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding a letter received by the ship "Non-such" in twenty-two days from Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a pass or exchange to enable him to go to England; has written to the Secretary of the Marine Department, craving his release; begs Franklin to use his friendship with the Marquis de Castries; comes from Hudson Bay and has been four years from home.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Du Trembley, Comtesse, de la Brosse. Void

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her brother served in the Count de Rochambeau's army in America; retired with the rank of Captain to an estate near Williamsburg, va.; has forgotten apparently to send her directions how to write to him; begs Franklin to forward the enclosed in his next packet to Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiry concerning Johann Jacob Hoefle, cooper, who went to Philadelphia in 1744. In 1750 he worked for Michel Diel or Thiel. Since then nothing has been heard of him.
(In German.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiry concerning Johann Jacob Hoefle, cooper, who went to Philadelphia in 1744. In 1750 he worked for Michel Diel or Thiel. Since then nothing has been heard of him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's kindness in sending him a packet arrived from Nantes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certifying that James Carr was in the service of the United States and sailed for Philadelphia on the ship "Active"; was captured by the British ship "Proserpine" and detained many months a prisoner at Forton, where he conducted himself with great propriety and good behavior.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's letter by Comte de Segur; her opinion of this gentleman. News of his sister [Mecom] who is low spirited at not hearing from him. Her son Ray highly spoken of by the President and tutors of the College. Suffering of the inhabitants of Rhode Island. News of various old friends.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II 233.
