origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the fleet being driven back by the wind. Impatiently awaiting information on their money affairs. M. de Rayneval's speedy return makes him hope peace is not far disant.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II, 231.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to see Franklin about an urgent matter relating to himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reasons why he has not been able to have the honor of Franklin's company at dinner; hopes he has completely recovered from his late indisposition.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The annexed letter to M. de Vergennes [2p.] contains some ideas engendered by his last conversation with Franklin; if the letter is not presented, begs Franklin at least to ask for the payments he points out; these are indispensable.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enumerates the vessels at l'Orient; their time of sailing uncertain; his ship ready to start at a moment's warning. Congratulates him on the conclusion of a war, which must terminate so favourably for America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a lightning-rod which he erected on his grounds which terroized the town and brought upon him an order from the police to destroy it in twenty-four hours as a dangerous invention; memoir he has written on the subject; the trial is to take place in Paris; awaits the result with extreme impatience.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deposition of Captain John Carey, sworn to before James Calhoun, Justice of the Peace at Baltimore, setting forth the abominable treatment he and his ship were subjected to by a French frigate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his latest experiment in turning pure water into air; deductions he draws from this concerning the early formation of the earth.
(In French. Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing their safe arrival a quick passage. Desires Franklin's sentiments upon the probability of a final issue. Informed at the State Office that advices had been received from New York in which Congress absolutely refused to comply with the agreement made relative to the exchange of prisoners; desiours of having this explained; chance of a ship being sent to l'Orient very soon; asks that all the English prisoners may be collected together at that port; repeated request for the release of Lieut-Col. Tarleton and Col. Simcoe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of himself, and his present position as a manufacturer at Rennes; difficulties he encounters in commerce; his desire to trade with America; encloses a letter from Messrs. Lacaze and Mallet of Philadelphia [2 p.] to prove his connection with that firm; begs Franklin to assist him to enlarge his business.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Dr. Franklin and Mr. Franklin to dine with him at the Hôtel du Parc Royal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Comtesse de Forbach begs Franklin to take charge of the enclosed packet for her eldest son. Awaiting with impatience the first news of peace.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lacepède, Bernard-Germain-Etienne de La Ville-sur-Illon, comte de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His profound admiration for franklin; this is shown in the first part of his "Physique Générale et Particulière" which he is about to publish.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pleasure he experienced at hearing that England was about to recognize the independence of America; congratulating Franklin. Desires to know if the Imperial flag can enter, without danger, the ports of Boston and Philadelphia, charged with merchandise for Ostend.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes to call on Franklin tomorrow forenoon to confer with him about important matters.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Impossible to obtain the certificate Mr. Deane desires until M. de Beaumarchais returns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Franklin on obtaining peace and gaining liberty for his country. Reminds Franklin to spend some day with them before he returns to the land of promise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Lady Julian Penn to whose case he doubts not Franklin will pay due attention. Congratulates him on the provisional steps taken towards peace; expects to embark for America as soon as that desirable end is attained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a packet just arrived from Philadelphia. All the public goods now on their way to Nantes and l'Orient; will wait however to see the result of the present negotiations. Ships now at l'Orient loading for Philadelphia; freight demanded for carrying the public goods extravagantly high; however expects to get them all shipped in good time.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Bingel, R. Haÿm en haute Saxe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to sent the enclosed to Mr. Schmidt at Germantown.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a work published by Abb"é de Mably, which the author presents to Dr. Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the receipt of Franklin's letter to the Comte de Vergennes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a package which he received for him from London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His many discoveries and inventions; reason why the Acad"érmie des Sciences is prejudiced against his work; value to America of his discoveries in the perfecting of agriculture.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a portrait which arrived from Vienna, care of the Comte de Mercy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has devoted his life to the production and preparation of salt; has read in the Gazette of the want of salt in America; lays before Franklin a project to form an establishment in America for the preparation of salt in various ways for the public.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. [de] Kampl, Counsellor of His Majesty's finances; his peculiar taste and genius for mechanical inventions; description of a life- size mechanical chess-player, one of his inventions, also a child of four or five years, who can utter the first articulated sounds. His own ruined state; his fondest wish is to be employed in the service of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for Mr. L[aurens]; thanks him for his kind attention to a certain proposal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There being no Consul of the United States at Nantes, applies to him for a passport for the vessel the "Camberwell," which is ready to depart at the first favorable moment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to find a place in his despatches for the enclosed letter to Robert R. Livingston.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Nouvelle Librairie de La Cour. Marmbeim

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Importance attaching to a knowledge of the great Greek and Roman writers; their plan of bringing out at extremely reasonable rates, editions of the Roman writers of the Golden Age; desires Franklin to take a certain number of each author, for distribution in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin his work; believes him to be the creator of America's independence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was second mate and carpenter of the brigantine "Active," captured by the British on her passage from Philadelphia; imprisoned in England; made his escape with five others in a small sloop; question whether she will be condemned or no; begs Franklin's intercession in their behalf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter which he begs may be forwarded to his brother in Boston.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's favor of Aug. 12th, 1781, gave the poor unfortunates of the "Revenge" hope of a speedy payment of their dues; since then, they have received nothing; bitter complaints of their treatment; implores Franklin to take some steps in their behalf.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On his passage to North Carolina will stop at New Providence [Bahamas] in the hope of procuring a clearance of a cargo of tobacco from that island to Europe; desires any assistance Franklin may render him, if it is only a certificate to the Governor, of his being a subject of the United States; expects to leave his affairs in the hands of Mr. Ridley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed of Lady Juliana Penn's intention to go to Paris as an advocate for the representatives of the founder of Pennsylvania; reasons why he did not offer his personal services; thinks this letter will be delivered by his intimate and worthy friend, Richard Penn, who inherits the traits of his great ancestor; his hopes of meeting Franklin in England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petition from six American seamen who escaped from Forton prison, scized a fishing boat and landed at Cherbourg.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. de Kampl, mentioned in his last.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Benjamin Morris, the youngest son of Mr. Samuel Morris.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Saint Esprit, Sœur Marie, abbesse du. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering Franklin their good wishes; their confidence in his charity makes them hope for the continuation of his gifts.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II, 235.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of their rendezvous at the Chateau of Marly; permission obtained to eat in the gardens or in the pavillion; names of those who are coming; provisions already purchased.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin the Scotch songs which he desired. Mme. [la Comtesse] de la Marck thanks him for the seeds and would like to get some more seeds of American plants for her hot-house. Assures Franklin of her affection for him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering Franklin a seat in their carriage to Choisy.
A.E. by Franklin. The party consists of Mme. Helvétius and the Alexander family, has accepted, and will return to Passy as early in the evening as circumstance will permit, and perhaps to dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranging for Franklin to dine with them and meet Madame Helvétius.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a little work of his.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to a plain dinner at 3 o'clock to meet Mr. Walpole.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Barclay, Mr & Mrs, and Mr Ridley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation to dine with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him the promised translation of the letter; found it a difficult task, having quitted her native and [Germany] at the age of four; asks pardon for the delay and begs to see him again, before returning home.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to breakfast with him to-morrow. Expects he will call in the evening to play a game of chess with her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Count Stroganoff has invited her and some friends to go to Sèvres to see a procelain service made for the Empress of Russia. Asks Franklin if he wishes to go with them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will call with her friends on their return from Sèvres to take tea with Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mme. Davies and Mme. Brillon await Franklin who had promised to come on Sunday evening to the salon of Passy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reply to Franklin's inquiries about her health. Is going to Paris to consult her doctor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Defending himself against Franklin's complaint that his paper is excessively clear.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of papers furnished by M. de Chaumont in support of his account with Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account with the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desired the Marquis de Castries to send Franklin the edict relative to the establishment of five packet boats; wishes Franklin's observations thereon. Begs him to tell the Comtesse d'Houdetor where she can get the big wire for a second electrical rod.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring the necessary orders for the sale of the two prizes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to Dr. Franklin's accounts.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A proposal for freighting vessels to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has fitted out a vessel for New England; desires letters to Messrs. Robert Morris and Richard Bache at Philadelphia. Mr. Dorsius at Charleston, and Mr. Williams at Bostort, in order that they may receive the cargo.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Deux-Ponts, Marianne Camasse, duchesse La douairière de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquries if Franklin has any messages to send to Germany or Lorraine, and if he received the scissors she sent him a few days ago.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs his help in pressing their claim to large tracts of land in New York and New Jersey, left them by her uncle Bickley, one time Attorney-General at New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is an American seaman and native of Cape Cod; petitions Franklin to obtain his release from prison at Dunkerque.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Congress, through Franklin, on the approaching acknowledgment of that independence, so gloriously fought for; his intention to embark for America and become a citizen of that country. Acknowledging his polite attentions to Dr. Shuttleworth.
A.E. by Franklin, Mr. Smith who brought this letter states that Mr. Harford is Proprietary of Maryland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites Messrs. Franklin to dine with her informally. Through a misunderstanding did not see them yesterday when they called.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a passport for a vessel loaded with machinery for him bound from Chester, England, to Nantes.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented from waiting on Franklin by a visit from Mr. Jay; makes another appointment.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a copy of the paper he gave Major Rob, that he may enclose it to Gen. Washington and get his approbation of the measure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presenting Franklin with an instrument, of his own invention, to be used in the marine, for ascertaining the position of the sun; asks no other recompense than some employment in Franklin's home; when peace is declared, desires to establish himself in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to send any letters for her by bearer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the approaching peace and begging him to dine with them on the 27th.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Absolutely resolved to go to America; begs for a letter of recommendation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning the papers containing accounts of two engagements between the English and the allied forces in America. Compliments Franklin on his progress in French. The only bad mistake he generally makes is in confounding the gender of words.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning certain kinds of stoves. Desiring Franklin's interest on behalf of M. de lan Porte, who wishes the position of American Consul at Teneriffe.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to wait on Franklin with a young officer, a son of M. Guéneau [de Montbéliard]. Messages from Mme. Martin de Sette, à propos of a consulship for her husband. Acknowledging the beautiful medal presented to the club. Question of electing Dr. Priestley a member of the Acadé des Sciences.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes to inquire about his health and says that his friends (herself and others) would like to pay him a visit that evening.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is very displeased with Franklin for letting her go away in the inclement weather the previous evening so late and keeping M. Le Roy with whom she wished to take supper. Has always tried to be agreeable to him, but will in future not expose herself to such a slight. Returns him his umbrella.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Dr. Franklin and his grandson to dine and spend the afternoon at her house.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking if he will introduce "La petite femme de poche" to M. and Mme. St. Auban.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Dr. Franklin to dinner.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin: It gives him so much pleasure and happiness to see her and hear her speak that he cannot but accept such a precious invitation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about an invitation which they had received from Dr. Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Noting that the honorary office of Venerable was unanimously bestowed on Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Released from prison in England, petitions for prize-money due him for several English vessels captured whilst he was on the frigate "Protector."
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John Oliver and Emanuel Miles. London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two American prisoners, residents of Dunkirk, France, confined in Clerkenwell prison, beg Franklin to obtain thier release.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires Franklin to procure him employement in the American army, or the position of tax collector on one of their islands.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Went to America as Director of Military Hospital in the train of Rochambeau's army; the breaking up of this army makes him fear the recall of his commission; desires letter of recommendation to certain commercial houses in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for letters of introduction to business houses in America which might employ him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to secure payment of her bill for board, lodging, etc., of two sailors from American frigates of war.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin that has had his first audience with the King and Queen as Ambassador Extraordinary of the King of Naples.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recalling Franklin's invitation to a subscription concert at his house on account of the expected presence of Lord and Lady Stormont; as the treaty is not yet concluded, Franklin may not care for an interview with the Ambassador.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Are sending one of thier sons to Boston with a large quantity of merchandise to dispose of. Request Dr. Franklin to give him a letter of introduction to some prominent merchant there.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for all his kindness to his brother and asking a continuance of his favor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to viser the due bill enclosed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pressed into the English army and sent to America; deserted twice and escaped to France; desires to pursue his trade of ship-joiner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petition from nine American sailors, who seized an English brigantine which was confiscated by the French authorities at San Domingo, begging Franklin to obtain the return of the vessel or its value to them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making inquiries as to the fate of M. [de] Mauduit Duplessis, a French officer, who entered the American army two years before.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his kind attention to the writer and his wife. Inquiries about his health and asks when he will come to see them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informs him of the great losses he sustained during the war, and asks him to induce Great Britain to make some compensation to the American sufferers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends explanation of the medal [struck in honor of the capitulations of Saratoga and Yorktown.] Thinks he has understood what Franklin wished, simply a description of the events designated on it. x
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Franklin and his grandson to dine with him. Expects to have Count d'Estaing. Asks Franklin to invite M. de Chaumont also.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a letter of recommendation to M. Duler, supercargo on the ship "Harmonie" bound for Charleston or Edenton.
(In French.)
